TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the new Parliament House, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard. In the interests of providing honourable senators with detailed information, I also table further data and graphical representations of the project budget and the Parliament House Construction Authority response to the Auditor-General's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
It has been the custom of this and past Governments to regularly review progress on the new Parliament House project and to report on that progress to the Parliament.
I will accordingly report on the nine month period to May 1987.
During this period progress was at a sufficient pace to open on schedule in May next year and for the Parliament to be operational by August 1988.
The building budget updated for the nine months to May 1987 now stands at $862.15 million while the budget for non-building items is $164.75 million.
The total project is therefore increased from $987.4m to $1,026.9 million at May 1987 prices.
This updating includes $24.6m for adjustment of the uncompleted portion of the project for the effects of inflation in the nine months period.
This procedure has been applied throughout the life of the project.

Additional components have been an allowance to cover the cost of industrial disputes, insolvencies of contractors and exchange rate fluctuations-costs outside the control of the Authority i.e. $9.9m, $4.6m and $.4m respectively, a total of $14.9m.
The five components of the total revised budget of $1,026.9m are:
the original 1978 building budget of $220m
the original 1981 non-building budget of $82m
the accumulated inflation escalation adjustment of $463m
an allowance of $66m for costs beyond the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority for industrial disputation, contractor insolvency and exchange rate variations; and
$196m for accumulated budget additions.
The $196m comprises:

$87m which should normally have been allowed for as contingency allowances including $36m for contract variations and contractors' claims, $8m for adverse ground conditions, $11m for changes to non-building items and $32m for associated fee costs on the foregoing items;

$104 for approved extensions to the building including $4m for placing the eastern carpark underground, $41m for accommodating additional Senators/Members, $9m for minor user changes, $20m for sound/vision equipment and furniture, $33m for design/user refinements and $9m for associated fee costs on the foregoing items. The overall cost of these additional items was subsequently reduced by $12m following a reduction in costs in other areas; and
$5m for reinstatement of landscaping.
The conclusions from this disaggregation are:
that the non-building budget ($82m) and the contingency allowance ($87m) ought to have been included in the original budget
that it was not possible to escape the effects of inflation ($463m)

that it was not possible to escape the costs of industrial disputation, insolvencies and exchange rate variations ($66m) which on a pro rata basis are probably less than would be experienced on most major construction projects anywhere in Australia, and
that the only other additional factors are the $104m for approved extensions such as when the size of the Parliament was increased in 1984 and the $5m for landscaping.
These figures therefore show that claims of ``massive cost over-runs'' are, in fact, a misunderstanding of the true nature of the disaggregation of the costs.
All this is not to say that in some limited instances, cost over-runs or control lapses have not occurred, but it clearly refutes these sensational claims of unrestrained cost blow-out.
The new Parliament House building has been created, designed, built, and furnished by Australians and Australian made products and artworks.

It highlights the pinnacle of Australia's talents, products and natural resources and should be a source of national pride. The construction phase has almost been completed. Nearly all of the external pre-cast concrete wall panels are in place and a large proportion of the granite cladding of the curved walls is completed. The flagmast is finished. Work on the Forecourt is progressing rapidly.
The western and northern sides of the site are almost clear and shaping of the landform is proceeding.

Internally, the building is taking on final appearance. The staircases in the Foyer are complete, the House of Representatives Chamber is well advanced as are the offices in that wing. In many places built-in furniture is in place, equipment has been delivered and soon to be installed.
Permanent power has been supplied to the north, south and east zones of the building and the central energy and air handling plant rooms have been commissioned.

So the project is well advanced. We can expect it to be operational next year. This is an achievement considering the constraints of design time, together with providing the additions required to accommodate the larger Parliament. It is a building of which all Australians can justifiably be proud.
The Project has, of course, as have previous major national, State, and private sector projects, been subject to some criticisms.
I have already generally covered the ``cost blowout'' allegations made by some sections of the media.

Also, the Parliament House Construction Authority has prepared a detailed response to the Auditor-General's report. This report was tabled on 2 June 1987. The report and the response will now be considered by the Public Accounts Committee in accordance with normal Parliamentary practice.
Perhaps the most unfair allegations made against the project involve misrepresentation of the project's industrial records.

I will not, of course, sanction unjustifiable work practices. However, some of these types of allegations have been proven wrong; in other instances, private sector industry practices have been wrongly presented as being peculiar to the new Parliament House site.
It has been asserted that the project has been a pacesetter for wages and conditions.
But the project has consistently been short of labour by up to 200 because of the attraction of other private sector projects in Canberra and interstate which offer more attractive financial rewards.

Because of the nature of the project it has often been the pressure point for industry-wide issues. For example, the 14 week dispute in 1984 was caused by industry-wide pressure to obtain superannuation and severance pay.
The Authority was congratulated at the time for not giving in to these demands and becoming a pacesetter.
As everyone would know, the new Parliament House site was also a focal point during the very difficult period while the BLF was deregistered.
The site industrial agreement has generally proved a successful way of resolving disputes resulting from on-site issues but cannot be expected to cope with industry-wide disputes.
Given the nature of the project and the potential for disputation, the Parliament House project has a reasonable industrial record.
There is little basis for claims that the project has ``an appalling industrial record'' or that it is a ``pacesetter'' in wages and conditions.

With a few notable exceptions, most unions on the Parliament House project have acted responsibly within the terms of the site agreement to create a safe and satisfactory work environment which has in turn generated a team spirit and pride in the project.
However, the Government is determined to continue the control that it has exercised over the past four years.
This project if it is allowed to run the course it is currently on, will be completed on time.
However, I must sound a clear note of warning. The run up to completion dates could be the most difficult and challenging phase of the entire project.
The Government will not bow to blackmail either by unions or contractors.

Industrial disputes or forced contractor insolvencies must not be staged in the belief that the Government would be willing to capitulate in order to have this building fully operational by August 1988. As I have said, this project has not been an industry pace setter. This position will remain. Building industry union claims should be processed within the Arbitration Commission's wage principles.
Contractors and unions should note this and act accordingly to ensure the smooth completion of this magnificent project.
The target dates for opening by the Queen are 9 May next year and for the new Parliament House to be operational from August.
These dates will be achieved with clear co-operation and commitment from all involved.
But if my warnings are disregarded, the opening will still be in May but the Government will make the necessary adjustments regarding timing of occupancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We received only very recently the statement of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and the accompanying document, which is the response of the Parliament House Construction Authority to the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the new Parliament House project. There is a great deal of material in the report which will bear further analysis and consideration by the Senate and by the wider community.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I make on the report, which itself is a response to the Auditor-General's very damning efficiency audit report of several months ago, is that in the Opposition's view it in no way answers the criticisms of the project that have been raised on this side of the Parliament and elsewhere in recent times. There is no doubt that for the new and permanent Parliament House this construction project, despite the size of it or perhaps indeed because of that, has suffered from inadequate procedures, management mistakes and governmental incompetence. No attempt by the Government or the Authority to rebut those allegations can deny the fact that this project has in many ways been bungled for a long period and, as a result, that has cost the Australian taxpayer a huge amount of money. We now have the situation that the total final cost of the new Parliament House is estimated in the Budget Papers to be in excess of $1,000m.

Work done, particularly by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, led so ably and diligently by my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume, over a lengthy period in 1986 and 1987 discovered that of that $1,000m-plus cost, wastes and unnecessary expenditure which should not have arisen totalled more than $200m. At a time when the Government is talking, quite correctly, about the need for major restraint in Government expenditure, to have a blow-out and wasteful and totally unnecessary expenditure of that amount, on top of the total outlay for the huge project which many people see as too high anyway, is a disgrace and an enormous cost to the nation.

As I have said, the document which the Minister has tabled is the Construction Authority's response to the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the project. As the Senate will recall, that report was tabled in the dying stages of the last Parliament in June and did not receive the amount of attention that it should have received, because of the pressures of the unnecessary winding up of the Parliament for a totally unnecessary double dissolution election. There was some debate on it in the last day or so of the previous Parliament and it is something that the Senate should come back to, which we now have the opportunity to do today.
The Auditor-General's efficiency audit report on the Parliament House project was a damning report. It found, and I quote from page 65 of the report:

. . . that the Construction Authority's operations had not been carried out in an efficient or economic manner. The Authority did not appear to be pursuing adequately its corporate objectives to function as an efficient management organisation and to achieve all reasonable economies on the project. For example, the Authority could have been more active in ensuring that the detailed design would lead to the construction of a building that would be economic to operate and maintain.

The efficiency audit report went on to criticise the method of pursuing many of the operations of the project, particularly the fast track method and other related issues. In my view, the Construction Authority's response, although I have not had the chance to study it as fully as it deserves, does not answer either that or many of the other criticisms levelled at it by the Auditor-General.

Mr President, we should accept at the outset, as did the Auditor-General, that the building of the new Parliament House has been a massive and complex task undertaken in very difficult circumstances. It is the largest construction project of its type ever carried out in Australia and it broke a lot of new ground. Obviously, one would expect some problems along the way with a project of that size. It would be churlish of us, on either side of the chamber, not to recognise the impressive achievements that have been made. There is no doubt about that. Equally, it would be quite wrong and we would be abrogating our responsibilities as members of parliament if we did not draw attention to the problems that have arisen as a result of governmental mistakes, managerial mistakes and inadequate procedures. It is the view of the Opposition that the Construction Authority has not responded to the drawing out by the Auditor-General of those problems in a satisfactory way. But, I do not place the blame entirely by any means on the Authority; the Government has a great deal of responsibility to bear in this as well.

One of the most extraordinary aspects of both the method of accounting in this project and the Construction Authority's defence of its position is the method of budgeting. The Authority, for example, says in its response that the project is on budget and will be within the approved budget, but that approved budget is a moving feast because it is a budget that is always varied to take account of cost increases or overruns, and they are automatically approved by the Government. That has occurred in the project for a lengthy period. Therefore, to say that the project is within an approved budget is to make a meaningless statement because that approved budget moves biannually and therefore has no relationship to the original budget.

The Minister tabled in conjunction with the Construction Authority's report details provided by the Minister for Administrative Services, a table and a graph showing the composition of the building and non-building items in the budget, attempting to reconcile the original figures with the final cost of $1.026 billion. In the very brief time that I have had a chance to look at those figures, they seem to bear out fully most of the complaints and points made by Senator Michael Baume and others earlier this year. There are some examples too of the cost additions that have been caused by quite stupid Government decisions. For example, the attempt by the Government through the Expenditure Review Committee to halt all landscaping on the site earlier this year and the subsequent changing of that decision appear to have led to an additional cost, on top of the original cost, of $5m for landscaping. That $5m will be met by the Australian taxpayer, for two reasons: first, because the Government took a stupid decision in the first place; and, secondly, having pressure applied to it, it correctly changed its decision. If the Government had not made that wrong decision in the first place, the Australian taxpayer would be $5m better off.

Other speakers from this side of the House will point in this debate to some of the other areas of this project about which we have continually expressed considerable concern. Senator Parer pointed out very assiduously many of the industrial relations rorts and other practices that have been associated with the Authority and the construction activity which, again, have cost the taxpayer very dearly. Senator MacGibbon, who is also a member of the committee concerned with this matter, has also been very diligent in pointing out some of the difficulties.

I welcome the response from the Construction Authority to the Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Report. However, I say to the Authority that, in my view, it has not gone anywhere near rebutting the very serious deficiencies pointed out by the Auditor-General earlier this year. When the history of this project is written, we will learn, hopefully, from the lessons of this project. In many ways, it has been handled in a manner very costly to the Australian public. I can well understand the views of many people in the community who, at a time when they are being asked to pull in their belts, very rightly say, `If that is the case, how is it that the Australian Parliament is approving the expenditure of this amount of taxpayers' money on the construction of an enormous building which is being handled with a considerable degree of incompetence and mismanagement, leading to an enormous escalation of cost?'. It is a project which I am sure we will all be very proud of in the end but one which warrants a considerable degree of criticism of the method used to reach that end.

I thank the Authority for at least producing a response; I thank the Minister for tabling it. I draw attention, though, to the fact that many of the figures that have been provided in the table and graph, by the Minister, showing the Budget composition of various items should have been produced considerably earlier. The Opposition called for the release of those figures before the election. The Authority at the time, I think in an Estimates committee in response to Senator Michael Baume, said that those figures could be released without any great difficulty. Then on came the Government's clamp on the release of those figures pre-election. It was a disgraceful pre-election ploy to shield and to hide from the Australian people just what was going on in terms of the expenditure on the project. It is only now, after the election, that the Government has seen fit to release those figures. The determination of the Government to resort to devices such as this to prevent the Australian people from being properly informed on matters of great moment in advance of their having to register their vote, their choice at elections, is typical of the deviousness and dishonest devices that this Government has been employing for a long period to keep many of the facts about what is going on in the country away from the full light of public exposure. The Government is to be condemned for that.

I hope that in the years ahead we will use the experience of the construction of this new Parliament House as a lesson to us all in various ways, particularly as to the great dangers that lie in store for us all when governments get involved in projects when they are not fully competent to undertake them. If we learn that lesson from this project we will benefit from it.

Of course, that leads into the much wider debate of the whole role of government in economic activity in this country and I think we will hear a lot more of that in the period ahead. It gets to the whole question of commercialisation, privatisation and the proper role of the public sector versus the private sector, but that is a much wider issue than the matter for debate today. I will leave the other points of criticism and comment on the Construction Authority's response to my colleagues as this debate proceeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The construction of the new Parliament House has been an impressive achievement undertaken in difficult circumstances. That is the judgment of its greatest critic, the Auditor-General. It is the judgment on the efforts of the Parliament House Construction Authority and all those involved in this enormous project. Yet this project has been subjected to immense criticism, and quite justifiably so, by people who, like me, hold the view that it is an impressive achievement undertaken in difficult circumstances. The belated revelation by the Minister for Administration Services (Mr West) in his statement of the nature of the enormous blowout in costs is bad in the sense that it is late. It is worse in the sense that it seeks, once again, to mislead this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most disappointed to see in the enormous volume of documents that we now suddenly have, which we are given the opportunity of dealing with, if I may say so, at fairly moderate notice on this very important issue, that so much of the documents appears to be part of a polemic aimed at denying-fairly ineffectually, I might say-the conclusions of the Waste Watch Committee. The reality, of course, is that within this outstanding project there has been a level of waste and inefficiency, and the Auditor-General has demonstrated that. The Minister says:
All this is not to say that in some limited instances, cost over-runs or control lapses have not occurred . . .

When one looks at the figures presented one sees no evidence whatsoever of any cost overruns or control lapses. It is as if everything was absolutely perfect, and we know that not to be the case. But let us look at the justification. The five components of the revised total budget of over $1 billion are given. At this point, I interpolate that the claim by the Construction Authority in response to the Auditor-General's efficiency report that it was common knowledge for some years that the thing would cost $1 billion is absolute nonsense. There was incredible silence from the Government and from the Construction Authority about what the real cost would be until the Waste Watch Committee revealed it.

Let us examine the `one reason or another' and look at the escalation adjustment of $463m, because both merit attention. The escalation adjustment of $463m hides a mountain of mistakes. It does not simply cover increases in costs. The Waste Watch Committee gave instances of contracts which had trebled in size.
