The Senate forced the Government to undertake to release that information. A motion was carried in this chamber, with the support of the Australian Democrats-and I thank them for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not opposed.

—As the Minister says, it was not opposed-because the Government knew that if there were a debate on that issue, its position would fall. It knew perfectly well that such a debate would reveal clearly to the people of Australia the disgraceful behaviour of the previous Minister-not the present Minister-who covered up this information, who prevented it being released, because of the impending election. Since the election, the Minister in this chamber, the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), has been behaving in a totally honourable way-and I thank him for it. He is now to provide this information. But we still have not got the details of the contract overruns. Where are the details of the contract overruns that the Parliament House Construction Authority and the Government undertook to provide in April of this year?

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I am sick of the cover-up and the pretence in this document-that there is no area in which there is any substantial waste or loss, that one can quite properly and easily see where everything went, that they are just normal escalations and few extra things that the Government asked for. That is bunkum. This statement is bunkum.

Let us look at what has really happened in regard to these escalations. If one adjusts the non-building items back to, say, May 1978, there was a reasonable starting point of around $280m. By March 1983-by the time the present Government took over-there had been something like a $240m increase through escalations. It is certainly a high rate of escalation, at a high rate of inflation. Given the revised basis, taking into account the questions of industrial disturbances, insolvencies and the exchange rate, if one accepts the Government's present view that there should have been some provision-let us assume a notional provision-one still sees in the first five years of the project that there was something like an 83 per cent increase in cost. At a time when inflation throughout the nation was regrettably very high-over that same period the consumer price index rose by about 58.2 per cent-the cost of the project rose by about 80 per cent and the inflation rate was almost 60 per cent, so there was not all that much difference.

But what happened from then on? The inflation rate in the four years from March 1983 to May 1987 has been about 34.1 per cent, but the project budget has increased by about 87 per cent, if one adjusts these figures for the appropriate provisions. That is more than double the inflation rate. What was going on? Why did these costs increase by more than double the inflation rate? Over that period, by the way, the Canberra building cost index went up by something like 47 per cent. It seems to me that hidden in this escalation figure-the Government dismisses it and says there is nothing wrong with it-is a massive volume of cost overruns which, quite frankly, I believe merit very close attention.

Let us now look at the $196m for accumulated budget additions. This comprises $87m which normally would have been allowed for as contingency allowances, and includes $36m for contract variations and contractors' claims, $8m for adverse ground conditions, $11m for changes to non-building items and $32m for associated fee costs on the foregoing items: thirty-two million dollars of fee adjustments on changes costing a total of $87m! If one subtracts the $32m one ends up with $55m worth of net adjustments and $32m worth of fees to look after these adjustments. What an incredible ratio! Does the Government expect us to take that seriously? Maybe there is a coherent explanation. If there is, let us have it in this kind of document. We should not be served up an incredible figure, an extraordinary ratio which seems to support the Auditor-General's comment that there is very little incentive to control fees and costs on that project. On top of that there is a figure of $104m for approved extensions to the building, including $4m for placing the eastern carpark underground, $41m for accommodating additional senators and members-thanks to the Labor Party for that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Be honest.

—The Liberal Party voted against it. There is $9m for minor user changes, $20m for sound and vision equipment and furniture, and $33m for design-user refinements-which, I presume, means people changing their minds. The Government seems to be at it again. It has changed its mind about the Speaker's chair at this late stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not fascinating? This is a classic example of what has been happening. A decision was taken 18 months ago to maintain tradition and to take the Speaker's chair to the new Parliament House. However, the Australian Labor Party has a philosophic objection to the traditions of this Parliament and to our links with British tradition and the Westminster system. It has no concept of the importance of the British Parliament, as the mother of parliaments, or of the historic nature of this chair and its components. To the Government, that is all beside the point. The reality is that a decision was taken 18 months ago to take a specific course of action. Belatedly the Labor Government has, once again, changed its mind. This has happened repeatedly. I refer again to the $33m of design-user refinements, $41m for changing the size of the Parliament and $4m to change the siting of a carpark. Design changes are a significant element in these costs. It seems to me that there is one significant point in regard to all these changes. I repeat what the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: All this is not to say that in some limited instances cost over-runs or control lapses have not occurred . . .

Where are these cost overruns and control lapses in this ministerial statement? They are brushed under the carpet. That is what this statement does. We have to take the Minister's word for it that there are cost overruns and control lapses only in some limited instances. We do not know what they are. We do not know how significant they are. We are asked to believe a Government which has deliberately sought to hide this issue to prevent it coming up. Belatedly, having been forced, the Government is giving the appearance of coming clean. There are many other issues involved in this matter, and I hope that we will have an opportunity of discussing it at some length on another occasion. I make the point that the Chief Executive of the Parliament House Construction Authority has noted-it is contained in the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report:
that equally as disruptive as user changes-
that is, changes by the Government-
are those which continue to be made by the Architect and the engineering consultants.

Here we have change, change, change, bringing about cost, cost, cost. We would never know of that sort of thing just by reading reports such as the one presented by the Minister. I think it is worth mentioning that on page 60 of the response of the Parliament House Construction Authority to the Auditor-General's efficiency report, the Authority states:
. . . in the period 1980-84 the project was below budget, allowing a small contingency amount to be built up.

It was below budget! What has happened since? I think that is a question which really merits serious attention. Much of the material in this report warrants a great deal of attention. If only we had the detailed responses that were promised to us, but hidden from us before the election, in regard to what has happened to the contracts we might be able to adopt a more informed view on what these problems really are. All we know, on the basis of information given to us in September and October last year, is that they exist. The Authority certainly admits that some things have gone wrong. It ought to admit that some things went wrong with cost control because it admits it in its response to the Auditor-General's efficiency audit report. It stated:
The Authority acknowledges the matters covered in sections 7.2.11 and 7.2.13 of the report.
That report is the Auditor-General's report, which related to inadequate control of costs. The Authority continued:

This is an example of Audit using reports and other initiatives of the Authority to suggest that it had found problems. In fact, these were matters which were identified and attended to by the Authority prior to the Efficiency Audit.

So the Construction Authority admitted that there were problems about cost control. Of course, we do not see an example of it in the statistics we have been given. It admits that there were problems but says that it found them out. Of course, it did find them out because it appointed a cost control expert called McCain to find out what on earth was going wrong. His report was called Cost Control Systems Currently Operating During the Construction Phase of the New Parliament House, Canberra. Because I revealed its existence in the Waste Watch Committee, it has now at last become a public document. I thank the Minister, who allowed it to be released eventually in accordance with the undertaking given by the Parliament House Construction Authority that it would be released when I asked for it in April of this year. We got it this week. Let us look at what the McCain report said last year. It stated:
The time is long gone when individual changes of mind or requirements can be accommodated and I would recommend that no such requests be accepted.
Requests are still being made. The McCain report continued:
The weakness of this situation-
that is, in controlling costs-

is the expenditure figures they receive from the various sources need not necessarily reflect physical progress-not being in a position to check same-the ultimate forecast cost to complete could be suspect.

Boy, oh boy, he spilled a bibful there! Apparently the Authority had no idea at that stage, because its system did not provide for it, just how effective cost control was in terms of giving an idea of the cost to complete the project. McCain is critical of the inadequate nature of the cost control. He then referred to cost planners. All the Authority had in the project was a cost planner. Of course, a cost planner is useful in the developing stage, but one must have a cost controller once the construction phase starts. This project did not have a cost controller when the construction phase started. I remind the Senate that the construction phase was about 90-something per cent under this Government. There is not point looking back to the previous Government and saying, `It failed to do this,' or, `it failed to do that'. That Government appointed a cost planner and that cost planner's task should have crossed over to cost control. However, the McCain report pointed out to the Minister:

Whilst they are referred to as cost planners, if the duties described in their brief had been the subject of a detailed written and agreed procedure with the Authority and then adequately manned to undertake such duties monitored by the PM-
the project manager-

they could easily have been developed as an effective cost control department. Provided of course, they had the full project management backing and authority to institute and monitor corrective action.
Mr McCain continued:
Discussion elicited the fact they did not have the authority, nor the structure, to impose any control on any of the departments from which actual costs emanate or are logged.

What an incredible, extraordinary situation! This Government was happy to preside over the biggest building project in Australia, the biggest project in which this Government has been involved, this enormous $1 billion construction job, although the cost planners did not have the authority or the structure to impose any control on any of the departments from which actual costs emanate or are logged. But everything in the garden is lovely, because the Minister says so. This sort of bunkum is the reason why the Opposition will not wear this report. It is absolutely extraordinary. The cost control investigating consultant, Mr McCain, said:
. . . It is too late on the Parliament House project to enjoy the real benefits of this important part of cost control.

It is too late! He was called in too late to have an impact on cost control. That is why the Opposition and the Waste Watch Committee are so up in arms about what was going on in that project. The response of the Auditor-General to this situation was inadequate. The Government was not being told by its own Minister what was happening on that project. The Minister's performance is absolutely incredible. The Government did not know the extent of the disaster, did not know that there was no cost control and knew nothing in reality about what was going on there because the Minister chose not to provide details in the biannual reports at anything like a reasonable time. Here we have the reality:
It is too late on the Parliament House project to enjoy the real benefits of this important part of cost control.

There is a touch of irony about this, because the response to the Auditor-General's Office by the Authority complained that the Auditor-General's inquiry was too late to be of benefit in the construction of the building, but too early to be able to take all the lessons of all the mistakes. If everything in the garden is rosy, one could not imagine that the Authority would have anything to learn about, or anything to put into effect, from the Auditor-General's report if one takes its response at face value, or indeed that there are great lessons to be learnt, because everything was done so beautifully.

The reality is that this project has had problems, as would inevitably exist in any major project. My concerns are simply that it has-it may be the Government's fault rather than that of the Construction Authority, I do not know-a tradition of not coming clean and of attacking anyone who dares to criticise it. As Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, I was subjected to incredible attacks by Mr Peatey, who claimed on radio that the facts that I was presenting-he did not realise that I had got them from his own Construction Authority-were all wrong. I asked him kindly to outline where they were wrong, and I am still waiting to hear. He said it was impossible that there were the contracts that I had outlined, with volumes of 25 per cent-plus increases beyond scope variations and beyond escalations for inflation. He said that that was all nonsense; but I got that from his office. I want a real coming clean. We have got a step in the right direction, and if the Minister in this place has been a factor in that, I congratulate and thank him, but it is a very hesitant step in the right direction. It leaves an enormous number of questions unanswered and, as far as I am concerned, it is inadequate.

However, I agree that there are some areas where I believe the Auditor-General was wrong in the conclusions that he arrived at, and where the Parliament House Construction Authority has a case. I am not dismissing it altogether. All I am saying is that I would be overjoyed to have the opportunity to get up and support the Parliament House Construction Authority in its entirety, if only it would not keep defending itself in an inappropriate way. All that we want in this place is the facts and the truth. I believe that the present statements do not provide us with those.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the response by the Parliament House Construction Authority to the Auditor-General's efficiency audit on the new Parliament House project. I am chairman of a committee on restrictive work practices that was set up by Mr John Howard. A study was done on a series of industries, concentrating on restrictive work practices. The first report was on the maritime industry and the second was on the construction industry. I would like to point out to the Senate that we produced these reports simply because of the major concern in the community at our lack of competitiveness and productivity, the effect on our balance of payments, what could be done about that and what were the major causes.

SPEECH.PARA: One area of great concern was the growth that has occurred over a decade or two of restrictive work practices within industry. Part of the construction industry report dealt with the new Parliament House-about six out of the 34 pages. The purpose behind the report was simply to flush out into the open restrictive work practices which have crippled Australia to a large extent. Unless something is done about them, they will lead us to a position where our standards of living will continue to deteriorate further and further. I know that the view of many people has been that these matters should be kept under the carpet. Our view is entirely different. Such things should be flushed out for people to see and be put on the table and the opportunity should be given to do something about them. The general comment I would make is that these types of practices are endemic in Australia. They apply to almost any industry.

The new Parliament House is a magnificent building. Future generations, no doubt, will admire and appreciate it. The point I should make-even though the report contains six pages of criticism-and the point I made all the way through, is that the new Parliament House is no different from any other construction site. But the concern I have is that it was accepted-although it is inevitable with a structure of this size and magnitude, paid for by the taxpayer-that it should be our responsibility to look at the issue. The Construction Authority and the construction manager had a special responsibility to make sure that the taxpayers' money was spent in the most efficient way.

Because restrictive work practices are endemic in the construction industry and because the new Parliament House site is no different from other sites does not make these practices acceptable. This is the point we are trying to get across. We have an atrocious situation when the terms of work at the new Parliament House are accepted as the norm, because of standover tactics by a few people who are in positions of power in the trade union movement. I make it very clear that I am not attacking the trade union movement per se when I make these remarks, but I certainly am attacking people who have got into a position of power, abusing that power because they know they are above the law.

I will recount a few examples from the report I issued on this new Parliament House. Every time, for instance, the construction costs exceed budget, the Authority gets a new, upwardly revised budget from the Parliament. Therefore, the Authority says, quite illogically, that construction costs are within project budget. Every time it receives an increase the project budget changes. That is a very happy situation for the Authority. But regrettably it is taxpayers' money we are talking about. In discussions with people on the site-both contractors and private employees-one of the difficulties we had in talking about practices was their own fear of reprisals. I have discussed this privately with the construction manager and the Parliament House Construction Authority and they deny it, but I can tell honourable senators from the discussions I have had with people that there are concerns that for those who had spoken out on previous occasions reprisals were so bad that they were nearly sent into liquidation or were concerned for their own physical being.

The sorts of things that occur are endemic in Australia and in the construction industry, but this does not excuse them. In fact, an attendance allowance is paid to people at the new Parliament House simply to go to work. According to one contractor, both employers and unions will deny-and they have denied-the existence of the attendance allowance, but it is paid, it is commonplace and it is called something else. The contractors who have resisted paying the allowance are under increasing pressure to pay it and to backdate it as well. One source has indicated that just to backpay the allowance will set him back some tens of thousands of dollars. We have what is commonly called the `nicking off' system. Paying attendance allowance does not actually mean employees will stay at work. The building site is so large that some employees turn up in the morning, clock on, disappear down a corridor with a wheelbarrow, never to be seen again for the rest of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incredible!

—It is unbelievable, Senator MacGibbon, that this sort of thing is going on in this very place at the taxpayers' expense. The only time that employees are guaranteed to be on site is on pay-day. Employees have been known to stay away for two days simply because a handrail was missing. Strikes have been caused because there was no water in an urn and no toilet paper in the toilets. Work on the site proceeds at a snail's pace compared with other building sites around the country. So in that particular area it is different from some other building sites. Sources say that it can take a month to dismantle a crane and erect it somewhere else, but on other sites the job can be done in a couple of days.

SPEECH.PARA: Crane drivers on the new Parliament House site are paid one hour's overtime each day as climbing time to get to and from their crane. When we first reported this it was claimed that two hours overtime was paid but I now retract that. It is one hour, as has been subsequently confirmed by both the Authority and the construction manager. More importantly, that climbing time now applies to people who work on fork-lifts. A person who works on a fork-lift on the new Parliament House receives one hour overtime for climbing on to his fork-lift. On investigation I found that that was agreed to by the construction manager and by the Parliament House Construction Authority. It was claimed that that was an economic deal because, if it were not agreed to, a crane would need to have a spare crew sitting around doing nothing while the crane driver was at work. By doing this, people could be interchanged from the fork-lift to the crane. From the Authority's point of view, and considering the industrial circumstances, it was probably not a bad idea, but that does not mean we should condone the fact that, in the first place, it would have had to have a spare crew sitting around doing nothing. Why could they not have had from the start a system for interchanging people between the fork-lift and the crane?

Of course, featherbedding is rife. There are three men to a crane and tradesmen have two labourers to carry their plywood around for them. On the Parliament House site there are seven full time union delegates, paid by the Construction Authority through the construction manager, who do not carry out any physical work whatsoever, but are paid simply to carry out their union duties. That may occur on other sites-I do not know-but it seems to me to be an awful waste of taxpayers' money, and I do not know that it has achieved a lot.

Strikes on the new Parliament House not only cost the taxpayer money but also severely affect contractors working on the project. One of the major cost increases outlined in the recent report related to the fact that there have been liquidations amongst the contractors. Over 200 contractors are involved in the construction, and it is alleged that many have been or are in severe financial difficulties as a result of the disruption and general industrial anarchy which has reigned on the site. The Parliament House Construction Authority claims that the cost of strikes has been $9m. I submit that the actual direct and indirect cost of these strikes is well in excess of that figure, because a large part of the liquidation costs would have occurred because of industrial disputes.

The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), in his statement in the other place, incorporated by Senator Ray here today, says that he would not sanction unjustifiable work practices. What a joke! These work practices have been going on for the last four or five years, since the darn thing started, but the Minister says that he will not sanction them. What has he been doing? It is a wink and a nod job. He says in his statement:
. . . some of these . . . allegations have been proven wrong . . .
They were proven wrong. I made a mistake. Instead of two hours climbing time for a crane on time-and-half, it is one hour. The Minister goes on:
. . . private sector industry practices have been wrongly presented as being peculiar to the new Parliament House site.

At no time did any of us say that these practices were peculiar to the new Parliament House site. We said that they were applicable to the whole of industry; but at the new Parliament House site they have made an art form of them. The Minister goes on:
The site industrial agreement has generally proved a successful way of resolving disputes resulting from on-site issues but cannot be expected to cope with industry-wide disputes.
I understand that industry-wide disputes can be a problem. The Minister goes on to say that he believes that, given the nature of the project, it has had a reasonable industrial record.

TALK.START.PARA: —A $27m strike a year or so ago.

—That was the strike that went on for some 14 weeks. An answer has just come before me to a request made by Senator Reid in an Estimates committee hearing in April last year. She asked for a summary of industrial disputation on the new Parliament House site. I will give a few examples of the disputes which occurred month after month. In September 1985 there were Builders Labourers Federation bans over trades assistants to fixers and glaziers; a BLF stoppage over the death of an employee; Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia bans arising from tower crane climbing times and crane shut-down procedures in high winds; and disputes and bans related to severance pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about severance pay. An agreement has now been reached between the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and employees for severance pay to be paid on the basis of a $20-a-week input from employers. Employees found that if they were paid severance pay on a weekly basis after a job had finished they were likely to have to pay tax on it. So they said, `We cannot have that. We will have to look at a way of avoiding tax'. We have had Senator Walsh coming in here and talking about tax evaders and welfare fraud, alleging that honourable senators on this side of the chamber support them. Yet here the Government, in connivance with these union representatives, is supporting welfare fraud and tax avoidance. They are saying, `Let us work out a scheme where you can get this money, paid for by the employer, and still get the dole. We are not going to act for the Government and take over the dole. Alternatively, we will give you a lump sum on only 5 per cent of which you pay tax and you can get the dole as well'. That is the connivance that is going on among Government members, those fraudulent people who, in one instance, complain about tax fraud and welfare fraud and, in another, aid and abet it.

That dispute started in September 1985. In October 1985 there were continuing bans over trades assistants to window fixers and glaziers, and FEDFA bans arose from a tower crane climbing times dispute. There was another litany of disputes in November 1985. There were disputes in December 1985 and January 1986. I could go right through the list month by month. In August 1986 the FEDFA banned overtime and the interchangeability of drivers. Presumably, the union was claiming that a particular piece of equipment belonged only to its members and that no one else could use it; so there could be no interchangeability of drivers. That sort of restrictive work practice is crippling this country and is costing the taxpayer a fortune, as in the case of the new Parliament House.

In the period between September 1985 and June 1987 I think that there was only one month during which there was not a dispute at the new Parliament House, and that was in December 1986. That is an absolute disgrace. The most despicable aspect is that it is all being paid for entirely by the taxpayers of Australia. Even though the Minister says that the project is no different from any other and that the workers on that site have a better record than that of anyone else, Senator Button is on record as saying, when this matter became a public issue because of the 7.30 Report, that there was no doubt in his mind that such things were going on at the new Parliament House. Senator Walsh, in his famed speech to the Labor lawyers of Western Australia, said that he also had no doubt in his mind that the new Parliament House was a scandal.

The new Parliament House is a magnificent building. It will be admired by many Australians for the next 100 years or more. But I repeat my concern about the fact that it has been used as a milking cow by irresponsible people, people who got themselves into positions in the trade union movement knowing that they were above the law because they had seen their colleagues acting above the law, to rip off the taxpayers of this country to an enormous extent. The Minister has put out figures concerning the cost increases. In May 1978 the estimated cost of the building was $220m. We have seen the cost rise and rise; it is now over $1 billion. Let us see what happens between now and the supposed completion date as a result of the redundancy scheme. There is a vested interest in this job being prolonged. I do not think that even Senator Robert Ray would bet with me that that will not occur. If it does not occur, it will mark a change from the normal construction practice, to which I referred earlier, in most construction businesses throughout the country over a long period.

I believe that the Parliament House Construction Authority has not done its job. The efficiency audit put out by the Auditor-General was the most devastating efficiency audit I have seen, certainly since I became a senator. I do not know how far back in time one would have to go to to find a more devastating efficiency audit. The Authority has attempted to respond to it. Some of the response was fair and reasonable. But generally the thing has got out of control; there has been no lid on it. Of course, a lot of this is not due to the Parliament House Construction Authority; my colleague Senator Michael Baume mentioned that an increase of $41m is associated with the extensions to the new Parliament House made necessary simply by the increase in the number of members and senators in this place. I accept the interjection made earlier by Senator Robert Ray during Senator Michael Baume's speech in that regard, but the Liberal Party of Australia opposed this increase in the number of members and senators in both places. Yet the Government went ahead and did it-to hell with the cost, and I refer here only to the cost associated with the new Parliament House.

I also understand that a large slab of the cost increases that occurred were outside the control of both the construction manager and the Parliament House Construction Authority; they were due to the Government's chopping and changing in its views. For instance, sometime last year it decided to limit the extensions to the new Parliament House. This involved having the architect re-draw plans and make new plans-a change of direction-and, some time later, a change back to the original plan and the same exercise all over again. That is sloppy. So not all the blame can be laid at the feet of the Authority; a lot of the blame has to be laid at the feet of this Government, where the ultimate responsibility lies.

As I have said a number of times, the new Parliament House will be a great monument to the future. Regrettably, it has associated with it cost increases and rip-offs of the taxpayer. I believe in my own heart that this is the sort of matter that warrants some sort of an investigation to see just where the real blame for this lies. It may not be too late for that. Certainly the blame lies ultimately with the Government itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the criticism from the other side of the chamber, we can be assured of one thing: come September next year Opposition members will gather their beds, chairs and desks and wander up to the new Parliament House. Up they will go.
—Don't mention the chair.
—Don't start talking about the furniture.

—I will come back to the furniture in a minute because I have something to say about that chair. Let us be clear about this: although honourable senators opposite have been very protective of the taxpayers' money being spent on this new House, as they should be, their consciences will not be such as to prevent them from joining in as we all troop up there ceremoniously led by our redoubted leaders to occupy the new House. No doubt we will all thank the taxpayers at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: But when I was listening to Senator Parer I got concerned about whether the House was there! Senator Parer said that all these work practices have delayed the building; they have done this and they have done that. But I will read from the statement to which Senator Parer earlier referred. This is the document in everybody's hands. It is a statement incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) on behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. Stewart West, MP, the Minister in charge of this project. The second paragraph of this document states:
. . . progress was at a sufficient pace for the new Parliament House to open on schedule . . .

I said to Senator Devlin, `After hearing Senator Parer speak about all these practices and things, the House could not be there'. But Senator Devlin assures me-and he is a man whose opinions I respect-that up on that hill now is a building near completion, one which will be opened by Her Majesty the Queen in May of next year. But Senator Parer mentioned all these work practices and things. How did this building come about? Did Senator Parer rush up and build it? Did he brush aside all these people who were up there indulging in these awful work practices? Did he put it up himself-because somebody has? In fact, I must quote Senator Parer's words on this. He said that the House was a `magnificent building'-a magnificent building which was built by these workers.

In the old days Australia was founded by the convicts, God bless them. They worked under certain conditions and they worked very effectively. We do not deny that. But things have changed and we really cannot impose upon the workers of today the conditions we imposed upon the convicts of yesteryear. I understand that perhaps Senator Parer thinks that we should.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had free board and lodging. What more do you want?

—That is exactly Senator Parer's point. The other thing I think we could say about Senator Parer's speech is that he has worked hard on his restrictive work practices committee. He has searched for and found work practices and he has become very indignant about them. Apparently it is only on the basis of his recent examination that he has found these work practices. I can tell honourable senators that he worked in the coal industry for many years, but he was not able to produce here today any examples of these evil work practices from the time that he was managing. In those days, Senator Parer was a good manager and he did not have this trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: I think if Senator Parer really analyses this well, he will find that if any of this trouble does occur, as he has pointed out, it is largely because of management. I am sure that if Senator Parer had been managing this site these practices would not have occurred. He has said, `Originally we said this was unique to Parliament House but we have done some investigations and we have found that these practices are not unique at all. Nevertheless, since we have done all this research and we don't want to throw out the research, what we will do is say, ``Even though the practices are common, they are very bad for Parliament House''.' What makes them bad is that the taxpayer is paying for it. That is fair enough. So he says to the Government, `Somehow, you change all these practices that have been going on for years. You, in some way, alter it. You get into the manager and into the workers and cure it all'. He gave an example of how work practices are bad-and I am sure Senator McKiernan will be very upset about this. He said, `One day somebody was killed on the site and the people stopped work'. He said, `Oh, isn't it a dreadful thing that, when somebody dies, the workers stop working?'. Perhaps in the past Senator Parer may have taken a day off work to go to a funeral. I do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasn't in the Senate on the opening day of Parliament.

—Not because somebody died, surely? Look at these disgusting work practices-workers stopping when one of their co-workers dies! This is the example that Senator Parer gives. I do not want to make any comment on his approach to life, but I just say that that is a common work practice throughout Australia. When my father died I took a day off and went to his funeral. I know that Senator Parer would not do the same, but I would like him to think that there is another element in the world besides economics. I get moved. I have a heart and a soul, and they are moved by these things. Senator Parer says, `Oh no, the workers cannot take a day off to go to a funeral', or if somebody gets killed on the site, he says, `Don't stop work'.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Cooney is misrepresenting me.
—Senator Parer, you will have an opportunity when Senator Cooney has finished his speech to claim that you have been misrepresented. I do not think that is a point of order.

—Senator Parer is a man for whom I have the highest respect. He, like me, is being paid at the taxpayers' expense and, like me, he tries to do the right thing by the taxpayers. As I recall, he said, `The workers stopped work because of the death of a member'. That is what he said; he might be able to check it. I take it from that, in the context that the honourable senator put it, of working and work practices, that he was criticising that as a work practice. I am not too sure whether the work practice the honourable senator was criticising was the death or the stopping of the work. But I can tell honourable senators that if it is the first it is terribly difficult to avoid.
—It is to be discouraged.

—It is. The other person for whom I have a great admiration is Senator Michael Baume. Senator Parer demonstrated the great work he had done in analysing and parsing out how the workers of Australia are a hopeless, inefficient lot. These are the people who have got to get their children fed. When I observe them they go responsibly about their work, they go home, and they try to feed their children and send them to school. They try to bring them up as decent citizens, so that they can vote in elections. These are the sorts of people I look upon as workers but apparently, in Senator Parer's view, they are to be condemned. In Senator Parer's view the ordinary, decent Australian is not worth looking at.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, let us leave that matter because we have Senator Michael Baume and his Waste Watch Committee. I want to join with Senator Baume in saying that he has worked hard and efficiently. That Waste Watch Committee is one of the great achievements of the Opposition. Senator Baume spoke about the Waste Watch Committee, and although we concede on this side that it is a great thing, we really should have been speaking about the ministerial statement which dealt not so much with his Waste Watch Committee-I would have thought that we ought to have a statement on his Committee-but with the new Parliament House. That is what we were talking about. The new Parliament House is a magnificent building. Nobody denies that. Nobody denies that what we have for Australia-this has been put in the statement; it was not criticised-is a new Parliament House building which has been created, designed, built and furnished by Australians and Australian made products and artworks. It highlights the pinnacle of Australia's talents, products and natural resources and should be a source of national pride.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the New Zealand carpet.

—The New Zealanders, as the honourable senator says, are really fellow travellers of Australians. We love the New Zealanders. I am not going to condemn and criticise that great nation across the Tasman Sea. Just because every now and then they beat us at some sport, I am not going to get nasty. If they can beat us on one thing, such as the carpet, I will still accept them-as would any decent rugby follower. I accept that they beat us on the carpet. But the general thrust of the building highlights the pinnacle of Australia's talents and should be a source of national pride, and what do we get today? People opposite do not look upon it as a source of national pride; they look upon it as a political point scoring exercise, introducing, as they themselves have condemned, politics into this debate. I know that Senator Robert Ray, who is sitting in the chamber, was quite hurt by the fact that they have brought politics into the discussion on the new Parliament House, this source of national pride.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume got very concerned about the chair. He said, `This breaks with great English tradition'. I think that is right. Just looking through the Constitution, it refers to the Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942. Let us abolish the Statute of Westminster because really that breaks the grand tradition we had as a convict colony with England on top of us. Perhaps we ought to abolish the Constitution itself, or get the English Parliament to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to examine the relevancy of this part of the debate.
—There is no point of order.

—It is very relevant. Senator Sanders, whose one great concern is the environment, is in commune with nature. It just shows honourable senators how good he is, because he can commune with nature in this chamber. He is away with the birds and away with the clouds; away with all the spiritual things-dancing, as it were, as a sprite amongst the sylvan trees. I will tell the honourable senator the relevance of it, and he should listen carefully. Senator Baume is saying that we ought to take the chair up the hill, because if we do not do that we will be breaking with tradition, we will be breaking our ties with England. How far do we take that argument? Do we say, `Look, we ought to bind ourselves to England to the extent that we ignore the great progression we have made from the times when we were a colony to the times when we were a nation'. In other words, it is time that we, as a nation, realised that we should leave this historical chair-there is no doubt about its great history-down here in this historic building and then take the next step in our history and go up there as Australians facing a new century, facing the changes which must take place. We cannot live in the past. History is a developing thing-it changes. If we had lived in the past we would never have got any anywhere. We would not have a Constitution or a Statute of Westminster; we would still be a colony inhabited by those people who made great contributions to our past, the convicts. That is the relevance of it, Senator Sanders. The honourable senator should listen. I know he is a man who has great spiritual dimensions, but besides having spiritual dimensions he has to have a practical approach to what is going on.

SPEECH.PARA: We then had mention of the slick cover-up. This must be the first of these reports that have been delivered to the Parliament. The document begins-this has not been denied:
It has been the custom of this and past governments-
`past governments', including the Fraser Government, under which this all started-
to regularly review progress on the new Parliament House project and to report on that progress to the Parliament.

There is no doubt that there have been regular reports to the Parliament and, through it, to the nation as a whole about the progress of this Parliament House. That is undeniable. Nobody from the other side can at any stage point to a cover-up. The very fact that the Auditor- General has reported is an indication that the whole thing has been open to public scrutiny. How can Opposition senators say that there has been a cover-up when the whole thing is reviewed by the Auditor-General in any event? The very stuff that the Opposition is using to criticise the whole thing comes as a result of the openness that the Government has shown towards the way that this building has been put up.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the Waste Watch Committee showed all.

—I will give the Waste Watch Committee a good point because at least Senator Michael Baume and Senator Short have done some work on this. But nobody else in the Opposition has. There are just the two of them. They ought to be praised because nobody else from the Opposition has really looked at this. The Opposition is so indignant about it all but only two of its members have even looked into it.
—A stepping stone to the shadow Ministry.

—It is just a stepping stone to the shadow Ministry. Senator Short is quite properly in the shadow Ministry, and I want to see Senator Michael Baume back in the shadow Ministry. Let us go through this. Criticisms have been made and what the Minister has done, in his honest fashion and at the first opportunity, has been to say that the Government will explain the situation. Of course, now that the explanation has been put out, people have said, `Oh, yes, you say that, but we don't believe you'. It is easy to deny. But on page 3 of the document is an explanation that nobody has effectively dealt with. About the cost it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The conclusions from this disaggregation are:
that the non building budget ($82m) and the contingency allowance ($87m) ought to have been included in the original budget.
That is all right. That is a matter of accounting and has been fixed up. The next point is:
. . . it was not possible to escape the effects of inflation . . .

Senator Michael Baume analysed that and, as was pointed out to me by Senator Ray, when talking about inflation he demonstrated quite effectively, as a sideline, that the rate of inflation under the Fraser Government was much greater than it has been under this Government. In any event, and leaving that aside, the fact is that inflation has occurred in this country. The next point in the document is:
. . . it was not possible to escape the costs of industrial disputation . . .

Senator Parer says that it is possible. But it is beyond dispute that industrial disputes do occur. The document goes on to say that it was not possible to escape the costs of insolvencies and exchange rate variations. I do not know how one avoids insolvency in the building industry. Insolvency in the building industry is a fact of life. It goes on all the time. To say that in some way the Government should have put the new Parliament House away from the effects of insolvency is just living in the clouds, living amongst that verdant forest in which Senator Sanders so happily roams.

The document states that exchange rate variations of $66m are probably less, on a pro rata basis, than would be experienced on most major construction projects anywhere in Australia. When Opposition senators went through this document, why did they leave that point out? It ought to be read out. The full paragraph states:

. . . that it was not possible to escape the costs of industrial disputation, insolvencies and exchange rate variations ($66m) which on a pro rata basis are probably less than would be experienced on most major construction projects anywhere in Australia.
We have heard three speakers from the Opposition, all of whom were armed with that document, and none of them challenged that statement. I will just read those few words again:
. . . are probably less than would be experienced on most major construction projects anywhere in Australia.

In spite of their ability to read every word in that document, the three Opposition senators who have spoken so far have not chosen to contradict that great statement. The next point in the document states:
. . . that the only other additional factors are the $104 million for approved extensions such as when the size of the Parliament was increased in 1984 and the $5m for landscaping.

Now we have had the great criticism, `Look, you should not have increased the size of the Parliament'. The new Parliament House will be there for centuries. Senator Parer mentioned 100 years, but I hope that it will have a longer life than that. It will be a great monument. There has been talk about the British tradition. The new Parliament House will last as long as Westminster. We could be looking at 1,000 years, yet we have had put this miserable-that is really the only word to describe it-argument that the House should not be of a size to accommodate the inevitable increase that will take place as this country grows, and grows in its greatness. Opposition senators, in the approach that they take, will be unable to sing with any sincerity Advance Australia Fair. They are right against that. They want the meanness in their speeches to pervade us all. They want to cramp the House and not make it an expansive place in which proper government can be given to Australia. The paragraph after the conclusions states:
These figures show that claims of `massive cost over-runs' are, in fact, a misunderstanding of the true nature of the disaggregation of the costs.

The Minister has been candid, and it is worth while taking this into account. But all this is not to say that in some limited instances cost over-runs have not occurred. Control lapses have also occurred. But the document clearly refutes those sensational claims of unrestrained cost blow-outs. In this statement the sensational claims are rebutted, and so they should be. It takes a meanness of spirit to search the books and, as it were, to search the circumstances under which this building is taking place, in order to find out areas of criticism. Anybody who has had a house built has to have been very lucky not to have had all sorts of problems with the builder. All sorts of difficulties occur in the building of a house. This is the most massive building that has ever taken place in Australia. Clearly, there would be some difficulties. But I think it is now admitted that to extrapolate all those difficulties and practices and say that they are unique and that somehow the problems involved in the building of this building are unique is simply to stare reality in the face and deny it.

The Minister has acknowledged, clearly, that there have been problems, but he has rebutted, as he should, the sensationalism that has taken place. Of course, this great building, this unique construction, this symbol of Australia's greatness is the subject of sensationalism. Any attack on that sort of thing does make the headlines and the leading articles. But all of the criticisms have been dealt with and it has been shown that, although there have been difficulties, those difficulties are by no means exceptional.

Again, reading from the document, it states that the building highlights the pinnacle of Australia's talents. That is what ought to be acknowledged. We have heard the criticisms. But let us look at the magnificence of this building and of the work both by management and by the workers who have been so criticised. It is a building which we can look at with national pride and which has been admired the world over. The workers who have been so highly criticised have been part of the effort to bring this unique construction to its completion on time. Let us hope that, when we go up there next year, even Senator Parer-certainly I know that Senator Baume and Senator Short will-will say, `Let us bless the workers who have given us these new surroundings'. Let us acknowledge the greatness in which they have done this. Let us acknowledge the great vision that politicians, not only from this side of the House but also from the other side, have shown. We are often criticised, but this building will be a symbol to us all and, through us, to the Australians who have had the good sense to elect us all to this place.

Instead of the Opposition compromising the opening so that people are dissatisfied and think that there is a conspiracy about the whole thing, that somehow it is a tainted project, let us look at it rather as the project that it really is, a magnificent symbol of the Australian people, a magnificent symbol of the faith that we have in the future-it does symbolise that-a magnificent symbol of all that is great in this country, and let us go to the new building with joy and not with some sort of miserable cantankerousness in our hearts. I do not want to anticipate what Senator Haines will say, but I hope her words are said with the joy she is capable of showing and not with the tendency she sometimes has to score political points in this area. We should acknowledge this new House for the great project that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time that I have spent in this place I have learnt that two things more than any others will produce lengthy and sometimes entertaining debates.
—That was very entertaining.

—Yes, I acknowledge that Senator Cooney is always worth listening to. He can often talk for 25 minutes and say very little at all, but it is almost always entertaining. For that we owe him a debt of gratitude since there are people in this place who can talk for 25 minutes and say a great deal and not be entertaining at all. We do need Senator Chaney, the chaff, along with the wheat from time to time. The two things that produce excited and lengthy debate in this place are changes to Standing Orders and anything to do with the development of the new and permanent Parliament House. In fact, on the first subject I have seen and heard some excellent contributions from honourable senators speaking about whether we ought to be entitled to read our speeches in this place. Interestingly enough, most of those contributions were made by speakers arguing that we ought to be able to read speeches, but not having even a note in their hands. So in this place there is nothing if not a mass of contradictions.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last few years the new and permanent Parliament House has produced some of the most interesting debates because, after all, we are the ones who for our sins will be living and working in the new and permanent Parliament House for as long, as Senator Cooney said, as the electors allow us to do so. We have a right to question, to criticise, to comment and to argue. We have had debates in this place, for example, on whether we ought to use rare woods in the building. We have discussed the use of cloth around the walls of the building, what is likely to happen with natural light coming in, with wear and tear and so on. We have discussed whether our corridors ought to be carpeted and whether the noise level ought to be taken into account. We have debated ranges of colour schemes. To the best of my knowledge, the people who have been in control of this entire system have paid very little attention to us. I had a discussion the other day with somebody who is involved in the project and who was commenting on the fact that we have natural light coming into the chamber. He said, `You people deserve natural lighting. You should not have to sit in a bunker'. As I said to him, we are here in hot daylight for about four of the 14 hours we are in the building.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but they have blocked off all the windows.

—They have here, indeed, but of what use is having natural lighting in the new and permanent Parliament House if we will be spending only a third or less of our time in the chamber in those daylight hours? It is a fine idea but it will not work in practice because we are simply not in the position of taking advantage of it for any significant time. Yet it will cause quite a significant problem for the cloth that will be used in the building, for the carpeting and so on. Inevitably, additional costs will arise out of that sort of decision. So we have a right as users of the new building to get up here from time to time to discuss its development, the length of time it is taking, the fittings and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are talking about a very significant blow-out in the cost. Madam Acting Deputy President, I stand here as something of a latter-day Cassandra-a Cassandra vindicated because back when the new and permanent Parliament House was first being debated one of my colleagues, Colin Mason, predicted that the blow-out would be from $220m to in excess of $1 billion. He was howled down as being unnecessarily pessimistic and critical. Anybody who thought about it ought to have realised that a blow-out of this magnitude was almost inevitable, given that we were looking at a complex project that had to be dealt with under a very tight time schedule. That brings forward all sorts of problems with lack of capacity to negotiate, problems of delays-in themselves causing problems-and, therefore, the possibility for pressure, if not actual blackmail, to apply in costings and so on. it was inevitable that there would be a factual basis for Senator Mason's predictions of nearly a decade ago that this project would blow out. Indeed, costs more than doubled in the Fraser Government years between May 1978 and March 1983. From March 1983 to May 1987, during the Labor Government's years, the budget has almost doubled. Almost 10 per cent of that increased cost in the years 1983 to 1987, I might add, has been due to the increase in the size of the Parliament for which we can thank not only the Labor Government but also the help it has received from members of the National Party of Australia in this place who supported Labor in its desire to increase the numbers of members of the House of Representatives and hence required the maintenance of the nexus in the Senate, giving us something like an extra 36 members of parliament all told.

The Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) has pointed out on page 10 of its summary of responses to audit findings that it has been known for some time that the budget would exceed $1 billion and that this information has been well publicised. I am not so sure about that: it certainly was not acknowledged until it got to the point where it could not be hidden any longer. It was not acknowledged back when this project was first argued for. The fact that 10 per cent of the increased costs in the last four years has been due to the increase in the size of the Parliament of course makes a mockery of one of the requirements of the design-namely, that competitors must do more than satisfy the immediate user requirements; they must also address themselves to the issues which will determine the success of the building in the long term. Among those factors included was a requirement for flexibility-the ability to accommodate growth and change. Yet the increase in the size of the Parliament has led to a $43m additional expenditure and we have again, according to the response of the PHCA to the audit findings, a problem in housing 180 additional parliamentary staff, estimates having indicated that those people will not be accommodated in the new building in 1988. The response from the PHCA to that criticism was simply to say that the building is built in accordance with the brief approved by Parliament. But, the brief approved by Parliament was for flexibility-for room to accommodate growth and change, and presumably at reasonable rather than at exorbitant cost.

The brief also includes among its factors a requirement regarding circulation. A system was required to provide for complex movement patterns of a large number of people. We have managed in this place to move a large number of people around in what I suppose must be complex movement patterns, if that is what they are called, with very few problems at all. Why there should be additional costs attached to this for the new and permanent Parliament House is beyond my understanding. In addition, the competition documents required that Parliament House must be more than a functional building. It should become a major national symbol in the way that the spires of Westminster or Washington's Capitol dome have become known to people all over the world. I have no doubt at all that the building is going to become well known, and deservedly so; it is a most attractive and a most unusual building.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has tennis courts.

—It might have tennis courts but it does not, to the best of my knowledge, have child care facilities, which are of considerably more use to the people who occupy the building but for which no provision was made, despite repeated requests over the years for some attention to be given to this matter. We can afford to make expensive additions to the Parliament House to accommodate another 36 parliamentarians at a cost of $43m, and we can afford to put in tennis courts, swimming pools, saunas, gymnasiums, and so on. However, we cannot afford to put in child care, not just, I might add, for the children and grandchildren of members of parliament when they visit here, but also for the staff of members and senators and for the people who work long hours in this place such as the Hansard staff, the parliamentary dining room staff and others, all of whom require those sorts of facilities. So that example, kindly presented to me on a plate by Senator Sanders, makes something of a mockery of the fact that this building is supposed to be more than just a house for members and senators; it is supposed to be something that can be used by all the people who come here.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is not a functional building. It is not a building that is usable in the sense that the Australian Federal parliamentary system has come to believe that we need. This building might be old and decrepit and added on to, and we might have to put buckets in the corridors to catch the drips when it rains--

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't catch them all.

—No, it certainly does not catch them all, and Senator McKiernan said that one. I recall that last year water got into the electrical system and the entire building was blacked out for which, no doubt, those people who were listening to the broadcast were duly grateful for a time. In any event, it is a building in which contact is easily made between members and senators, between backbenchers and ministerial staff, and between Opposition and Ministers. Now we are about to give ourselves a building in which there is an Executive bunker, in which not only are Ministers cut off from access to and by ordinary members and senators, but also they are cut off from their own back bench. I am not heavily into conspiracy theories as you would well know, Madam Acting Deputy President, being a friend and colleague, but I perceive in this an attempt by members of the Executive to make themselves less approachable, less accountable, to not only the Opposition parties, but also their own back bench.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, the layout in the rest of the building is odd. The Government party room, for those honourable senators who have not seen the plans, is between the office of the Leader of the Australian Democrats and the office of the Leader of the National Party of Australia. So there are not going to be too many party meetings that can be held without those of us on the Opposition benches knowing what is going on. From my memory of the plans, there are two ways into the party room: one is to come past the office of the Leader of the National Party and into the corridor leading to my office; and the other is to walk through an open courtyard and go in the back way. Presumably that gives some flexibility in pleasant weather but not too much when it is coming down by the bucket load as it frequently is in this place.

It is hardly a user-friendly building. I think that makes all the more appalling the fact that this blowout has occurred. It would have been bad enough if the building had been going to fulfil its basic function of housing members of parliament in any meaningful and useful sort of way but, apparently, it is not even going to do that. Legitimate concerns have been expressed by the Auditor-General and by others here with regard to the cost blowout and with regard to the fittings. Senator Barney Cooney mentioned the furniture a while ago and promised that he would come back to it but did not. The furniture, too, has been a source of problem. Large amounts of money have been expended on ergonomic prototypes and when we have gone to a committee room to test them, it has turned out that they tend to chop one's knees off if one is one height and one's shins if one is another height, and to take one's fingernails off when one pulls out the little sliding desk thing if one is not very careful.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not supposed to have dragon lady type fingernails.

—I do not have dragon lady type fingernails. If one does not have fingernails it takes off the top of one's fingers. So one has a choice. Those sorts of things have cost a large amount of money. I can remember an earlier debate in this place when I, along with others such as Senator MacGibbon, was complaining about these costs, asking why the authorities did not go to a car manufacturer to find out how to design the best sort of seating that would suit most shapes and sizes-and heaven knows we have a wide variety of those in this place. The old furniture has done us reasonably well. There should have been a more sensible and less expensive way of going about finding furniture to put in the chambers and elsewhere than the one that was adopted by the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: So there are legitimate criticisms with regard to this cost blowout.
