SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement relating to the defence budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Defence Budget for 1987-88 is the first in which the delineation of Australia's Defence Force for the 1990s and into the 21st century can clearly be separated from the concepts and strategies of the 1950s and 1960s. The Australian Defence Force of the future will be more capable; a co-ordinated fighting machine, rather than three largely separate services; and equipped and trained to prevail against any credible threat in Australia's area of direct military concern.
This Government believes in a self-reliant defence of Australia. It believes that our people should know that this is possible. That Australia can do it, can afford to do it, and must do it.

This Government believes that our service men and women should know that they are members of an organisation that has clear cut direction; that they are at the heart of the most fundamental of national responsibilities-the security of the nation; and that the Government takes its responsibilities for defence seriously.
The Australian Defence Force now has that direction and, as demonstrated in this Budget, the Government will provide the resources for the reconstruction of our fighting capabilities.
Efficiency improvements in the last two years are now providing a dividend to defence. Further funds for high priority activities will flow from management changes now being undertaken.

Each of the three Services is being re-equipped with the best and most appropriate weapons, missiles, transport and support equipment that money can buy. The command and control of the ADF is being refined and centralised under the Chief of the Defence Force because the Government intends that, should Australians again be called upon to fight, they will for the first time fight as an Australian Defence Force and under Australian National Leadership, rather than as part of some larger nation's force.
Our national surveillance capability is being revolutionised, based on Australian technological excellence in the Jindalee over the horizon radar.

The role of the reserve forces has been given higher status than at any time since World War II. In any future time of national military crisis the reserves will be critical to our survival. The rejuvenation of the reserves, the improved recruiting and particularly improved retention show that this is recognised.

Industry has been brought into the Australian defence network. At some cost to the defence budget the capability of Australian industry to produce, support and maintain defence equipment has been dramatically upgraded in the last few years. The submarine project will take this process even further.
Within the ADF the new posture of self-reliance, the emphasis on the north and the strategy of defence in depth have required rethinking of old ideas at all levels.

The opening of a new RAAF base at Tindal, the expansion of HMAS Stirling to be the base for half the Australian fleet, the transfer of battlefield helicopters to the Army, the requirement to manage over 100 major equipment projects and to bring the new weapons, systems and equipment into service are all providing new pressures in the ADF.
The fact that the cost of the new equipment program demands constraint on personnel numbers does increase the pressure.

I am pleased to be able to report to the Parliament that the ADF is responding very well. Australia's service men and women did not join up for an easy life. They joined for a challenging life and to serve their country.

There is growing evidence now that the Australian public understands the vital role our service men and women are playing. The public is throwing off the mental shackles that years of miseducation on our alleged inability to defend ourselves imposed. The enormous support defence open days and displays now draw is but part of this evidence. Among young people there continues to be a strong desire to join the forces. We must make sure that the enthusiasm that brings them in continues to motivate them through their service career.

To keep that enthusiasm our service people need to be aware not only of the challenges but also the opportunities. Our re-equipment program is producing opportunities for involvement in the use of advanced technology. Service conditions are changing, albeit slowly, to reflect the realities of the community expectations on lifestyles. That those changes are occurring has not been fully understood in the Services or the community.

To explain the changes and to ensure that the conti-nuing needs of service personnel remain in focus in Government decision-making were the major reasons for appointment of a Minister directly concerned with this area. The opportunities are there for fully satisfying service needs.

This year's Budget follows one of the most extensive and far reaching periods of review and reassessment in Australia's defence history. In a little over three years the Government has provided shape and structure to the concept of defence self-reliance and an ordered and rational approach to fill the gaps in capability. The same ordered and rational approach has been applied to defence management, both in the Defence Department and Defence Force.

By seeking efficiency from improved management and rigorous internal review and control, Defence is able to shift resources to enable the Government to correct the deficiencies identified in the White Paper and to get more capability at the sharp end.

The defence budget for 1987-88 is $7,404m. The Budget is a 2.7 per cent increase in dollars and a 1 per cent real reduction compared with 1986-87. I would add that these figures must be seen against the backdrop of the 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth outlays in the overall Budget for 1987-88. These statistics demonstrate a continuing strong commitment by this Government to our defence requirements.

In the past four years defence spending was insulated from the effects of currency fluctuation while we shaped the strategy and direction for defence self-reliance and put in place the machinery for the management improvements that produced an efficiency dividend. These two key initiatives enable this year's Budget to be held at $7,404m without affecting the blueprint for the next 15 years provided by the Government's 1987 defence policy information paper.

On 19 March this year I presented in this place the defence of Australia policy information paper. In conclusion I observed that `whatever his critics might think of the Dibb Review it has set a new standard for defence debate in Australia. Never again will those who wish to participate in the defence debate in this country simply be able to run off at the mouth with wish lists, persiflage and grandiloquence'. I said, `The program outlined in the White Paper is a prudent one, with clear cut priorities. It is based on a realistic assessment of our circumstances and our important alliance relationships. We are a powerful nation in regional terms, but with some serious deficiencies. We could not now deny ourselves self-reliance in the terms set out in the White Paper. The goal is achievable'.
The central message of this defence budget is that the White Paper is on track and will stay on track.

Defence self-reliance is realised through a strategy of defence in depth. It gives priority to meeting any credible level of threat that could occur at relatively short notice in Australia's area of direct military interest, that is, the area in which developments can most directly affect our security.
It means that any potential adversary knows that he will be faced with a comprehensive array of military capabilities, both defensive and offensive.

The Government believes that our focus on credible contingencies strengthens the priority needed to be assigned to the major elements of our capital equipment vote. To be distracted from this course could thus leave holes in Australia's total defence capability.

The Dibb Report and the White Paper have shown the direction that the ADF should go to take it out of the 1960s and into the 21st century. Force structure developments have emphasised intelligence and surveillance, strike and interdiction, upgrading maritime warfare and mine countermeasures capabilities, increasing the Army's capability for dispersed northern operations, enhancing command, control and communication systems and streamlining administration and logistics.

The emphasis on these areas is being reflected in the type of equipment being introduced into the ADF. It is access to adequate intelligence and effective surveillance that gives the defence forces of a relatively unpopulated country such as ours a chance to respond to threats in timely fashion. Timely intelligence is necessary to allow us to respond appropriately to any developing threat.
Some of our most effective indigenous scientific developments are associated with attacking these problems.
In this regard, I would like to emphasise the contribution of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in developing capabilities that are appropriate to Australian strategic requirements.

For example, DSTO is developing a towed acoustic array which is a sensor to be used from specialist surface ships and from our new submarines and which will provide wide area surveillance in important ocean basins and focal areas. Australia is a world leader in this field.

The emphasis on surveillance capability is highlighted by the continued development of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. This is the world's most advanced long range radar and represents a wide area surveillance capability that is essential to the ADF's force structure. It is another of the developments of DSTO's of which we can be justifiably proud. This year $16m is being spent on upgrading the Alice Springs site and I hope later this year to announce the next phase of this important project-the acquisition of computers and the development of specialist software.

Our Navy and our maritime warfare capacities are undergoing a massive restructuring and improvement of capability. Individual programs generate excitement in Australian industry with the attractiveness of their new technologies but their importance to the new strategy is sometimes missed. Our Navy is developing the ability to protect vital choke points, patrol considerable distances, sweep our ports clean of mines and strike an enemy's forces at source. In the debate that surrounded the decision by the previous Government not to proceed with the aircraft carrier, endorsed by ourselves, the considerable potential of our maritime forces was obscured.
A Navy with these tasks is going to look different from a Navy focused on force projection. However its role in the contemporary era will be more vital.

The six new Kockums type 471 submarines to be built in Australia to replace the Oberons will be the largest, longest ranging and most lethal conventional submarines in the Western world when they enter service in the 1990's. The new submarines will increase our maritime surveillance capabilities, as well as providing a formidable strike capability.

The great significance of our submarine fleet runs in tandem with the major upgrading of the maritime warfare capability of our surface fleet. It will leave us with a major increase in the number of platforms. The increased numbers are no accident. They are a result of addressing the enormously difficult problems of simultaneously confronting our need to defend the choke points to our north and south and develop a capacity to patrol further afield in areas such as the South Pacific.

The size of the surface combatant fleet when this Government was first elected was related to keeping one aircraft carrier battle group operational. Not only was the concept inadequate for the strategy of forward defence and power projection applied in the 1950's and 1960's, but that size force-12 destroyers and 20 patrol boats-was clearly insufficient for the defence of Australia itself. This position is being rectified now with the creation of a rational structure of three levels with the numbers in each related to the tasks and capabilities required for maritime warfare within the strategy of defence in depth. This will be a substantial improvement in defence planning over the largely `rule of thumb' approach of the past.

The surface fleet will contain three broad levels of capability. The highest level will be represented by the larger ships-destroyers and frigates; the second level by the new light patrol frigates and the third by the patrol boat force.

At the highest level of capability, $116m is to be spent on two new FFG-7s being built at Williamstown Dockyard and $45m towards modifying three of the existing four FFGs to carry the new Seahawk helicopters.
The first two of 16 Seahawks are scheduled for delivery in November 1988 with $141m in this year's Budget.

Three of the guided missile destroyers are to be modernised at Garden Island dockyard at an estimated cost of $385m, with $72m in this year's Budget. The modernisation will upgrade weapons and sensors and generally extend the operational life of the ships. The first two ships will complete the modernisation program in 1988 and 1989, with the third to complete in 1990.
At the middle level of the fleet of surface combatants, we plan to construct in Australia eight light patrol frigates for the RAN and up to four for the Royal New Zealand Navy.

The new light patrol frigates will be suitable for dealing with lesser forms of military pressure and capable of extended patrols within our resource zones and proximate waters in our area of direct military interest. They will have superior range, endurance, sea-keeping and survivability compared with patrol boats and will be able to carry the Seahawk helicopter.
They will be designed so that their sensors and weapons can be enhanced to enable them to contribute in more substantial contingencies.
On 9 September I announced the selection of three ship designers to further develop their ship designs for the Anzac light patrol frigate project.
A ceiling cost of $3.5b has been set for all activities associated with the procurement, outfitting and support of the eight ships for Australia.
The Government has also given a high priority to the development of a capable mine countermeasures force to ensure that our ports can be kept open.

Our strategic circumstances dictate that we need both a minehunting and a minesweeping capability. Minehunters are designed to use a forward-looking specialist sonar to hunt mines and then to detonate them using charges placed by a remotely piloted submersible vehicle. Minesweepers are needed to complement the minehunters by operating in deeper waters where the nature of the seabed makes hunting less effective.

In the air, Australia's strike and interdiction forces can hit further, faster and harder than ever before. The Air Force is being re-equipped to play its role in the defence in depth strategy. This means high-technology aircraft, sensors and weapons with the range and power to find and destroy targets anywhere in our area of direct military interest.
The Air Force will get another 18 F/A 18s this year, making a total of 44. By 1991, there will be 75.
The F/A 18 is a combined fighter and strike aircraft which carries the best radar and weapons for Australia's air defence, ground attack and strike needs.
One squadron will be based at a major new air base at Tindal, near Katherine in the Northern Territory.
A major upgrade is being considered for the F-111s, to maintain and enhance the long-range, highly accurate land-strike capabilities which they provide the ADF.

A new training aircraft, the PC9, is being built in Australia for the Air Force. It is the best basic trainer aircraft in the world, and it will allow the Air Force new, more flexible and more economical training programmes.

A new air-to-air refuelling capability is being developed in the ADF to increase the range of the F/A 18s, and a string of bare bases is being built across Northern Australia from Learmonth to Cape York.

Focusing on the defence of Australia rather than the defence of the Mekong has meant a substantial rethink in the Army. The Army is being re-equipped literally from the boots up to carry out its role of defending Australia. Tactical and strategic exercises are increasingly looking towards the areas in the north in which the ground forces will operate.

In 1989, Exercise Kangaroo 89 across the north of Australia will be the biggest peacetime exercise ever carried out by the Australian Defence Force. The soldiers will have new individual and light support weapons-the 5.56mm Steyr and Minimi-with deliveries from Australian factories beginning in 1989-90. Operations will be supported by new field guns-the 105mm Hamel, again manufactured in Australia, and troops transported by Blackhawk helicopters in the biggest upgrade to Army mobility in the last 20 years. We are also considering the acquisition of wheeled armoured vehicles for operations in northern Australia, and the possible upgrading of part of the fleet of M113 light armoured fighting vehicles.

Ongoing projects to upgrade Army mobility include the purchase of a further 600 four tonne Mercedes Benz Unimog trucks at a project cost of over $57m and the purchase of 330 Land Rovers at a total cost of $145m, of which $22m will be spent this financial year.

Initiatives to upgrade our communications capability include a number of projects using the latest communications technology. Examples include new Raven tactical battlefield radios, cryptographic equipment as well as the continued development of the DISCON (defence integrated secure communications system) which is planned for completion by the end of 1991.

Another important continuing communications development is the Defaussat project, which will provide an enhanced use of Aussat by defence, including field use by the ADF through transportable earth terminals. The system should be operational by 1989.
The White Paper recognises that our people-the men and women of our fighting forces-are our most valuable asset and a vital resource in the security of this nation.
A capable Defence Force needs capable people.

But along with the need, indeed part of the need, for a capable Defence Force is the need for the Government and the community to recognise the special demands that are placed on servicemen and women and their families as a result of service life.

In establishing the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, the Government broke new ground in pay fixing machinery. A range of pay and allowance matters are currently being addressed. We have a positive program in place to improve defence housing, and some key recommendations of the Hamilton report have already been implemented.
I spoke earlier on the strategy of defence in depth. Let me give some detail on the changing focus in defence activity resulting from defence in depth.

Any force hostile to Australia must attempt to advance in ships or aircraft. Accordingly, the program gives priority to the air and sea defence in our area of direct military interest; particularly to the north as this is the region through which major threats must pass.
Australia's long range strike capabilities are being developed to respond-quickly and lethally-to early warnings far from Australia's shores. These include air and naval forces.

Our air strike forces operating from bases in the north will comprise squadrons of F-111 long range strike aircraft; F/A-18 multirole aircraft and P3C long range maritime patrol aircraft. In all, over one hundred of these aircraft will be capable of carrying the Harpoon anti-ship missile; the F-111 and F/A-18 aircraft are also fitted for the Sidewinder air-to-air missile, and the F/A-18 also carries the Sparrow air intercept missile.

Australia's long range forces are also capable of striking land targets such as enemy bases and force concentrations. The F-111s are the central element of our land strike forces and the Government is seeking advice on a major upgrade of these aircraft to maintain them in service.

Installation of the precision target acquisition tracking and designation system in the F111 bombers is proceeding with 12 aircraft now modified and in service. Six million dollars has been allocated to the project this financial year.

The effectiveness of the F/A-18s for long range missions is being greatly enhanced by the Government's decision to provide aircraft refuelling. The first of the RAAF's four Boeing 707 aircraft to be fitted with this capability will be available in late 1989 or early 1990.

We are also completing a comprehensive network of air bases in the north to support these operations. In addition to the major airbase nearing completion at Tindal, a bare base exists at Learmonth in Western Australia and another is being built at Derby in north-west Western Australia. The Government also intends to build an airfield on Cape York Peninsula and to have it operational as early as possible in the 1990s.
Recent measures to rationalise assets and boost northern surveillance capacity have included changes to patrol boat basing.

Of the five Fremantle class patrol boats based at HMAS Waterhen in Sydney, one will transfer to Cairns, two to Darwin, and the remaining two will transfer to the reserves-one for the Sydney port division and one for the Melbourne port division.

This shift is a good example that cost cutting and strategic concerns are often compatible if innovative management is brought to bear. The shift to Cairns is both good defence and good economics. The operational expenses of commanding the patrol boat fleet from Cairns are considerably less than from Sydney. The strategic advantages are that the patrol boats will have quicker access to, and extended cruising time in our northern waters. The Cairns command basing is likewise more relevant to the increased emphasis on patrol boat activities in the south-west Pacific.

Another initiative is the Government decision to strengthen our northern defences by basing major elements of the Australian Army permanently in northern Australia for the first time in peacetime. Two cavalry regiment of 340 men and associated vehicles will be based in the Darwin area. This transfer will be complete by the end of 1992.
The White Paper goal of greater defence self-reliance has resulted in greater priority being given to the reserve forces.

One thing is crystal clear-we cannot achieve self-reliance without the reserves. Gone are the days of the reserves being seen as providing a basis for expansion during national mobilisation in some distant future. The reserves are an integral and essential part of our defence planning and of our force structure now.

The role of the reserves is being substantially widened. Navy reservists will play a vital role in mine countermeasures to safeguard our ports and shipping lanes, while RAAF reservists will be integrated into various units of their host formations to provide an expanded capability. It is in the Army Reserve, which provides the majority of reserve manpower, that the introduction of a total force concept can most clearly be seen.

`Total Army' means integration of regular and reserve forces at unit and formation level. This will allow elements of an upgraded reserve to enter the operationally ready first line, while the remainder will form the important base element for any rapid expansion at a time of increased tension.

The Army Reserve will be required to assist in the surveillance of the country's north. In recent years increasing emphasis has been given to regional surveillance units in the north and north-west and these are predo-minantly reserve units. Access to local knowledge and skills in remote areas of Australia could prove vital for the early detection and countering of a military threat.

In the more credible contingencies most likely to occur in the north and north-west of Australia, the Army Reserve will have a critical role in the protection of key areas, releasing regular units to conduct offensive operations. Such key areas would include protection of the Darwin-Tindal region, and the Learmonth, Derby and Cape York airfields, and other civil and industrial infrastructure.

It is intended that the reserves take a greater responsibility for heavier capabilities, such as tanks and medium artillery, as part of the expansion base. One armoured regiment, for example, will become an integrated regular and reserve unit.
The reserves now have a sense of purpose and they can take pride in the fact that they will be directly involved in the defence of Australia.

Reserve recruitment and retention rates are both up. Total reserve force strength increased over the year from 25,977 on 1 July 1986 to 27,673 at 30 June 1987. The strength of the Army Reserve at 30 June this year was 24,632, which was 132 above the target strength of 24,500 for 1986-87 and closing in on the authorised ceiling strength of 26,000 which is to be achieved by 30 June 1988.
The retention rates are comparable with other Western nations and, indeed, are the best figures in well over a decade.

One further initiative is central to the Government's perception of the new role of the reserves. Legislation passed in June of this year for restricted call-out of reserve forces in situations other than in war or a proclaimed state of defence emergency is a key factor in defining the role of the reserves in the full range of credible contingencies.
This means that reserves are now available to be used in the sort of low-level threat which could emerge with relatively little warning.
Steps will be taken to protect reservists' employment following call-out.

Although defence self-reliance is the major theme of the White Paper, the Paper makes it quite clear that this can be achieved only within our current alliance framework. The U.S. alliance does not suggest an unhealthy dependence on the U.S. rather it results from a mature recognition by both nations that their own self-interests are best served by the relationship.

Much of the debate in the community on the value of the U.S. alliance remains sterile. There is too heavy a focus on very unlikely contingencies such as global nuclear war or on the reliability of either partner to guarantee uncritically a force commitment on the basis of the other partner's political judgment. This level of debate is misleading.

The nature of an alliance partnership where a threat is not clear cut is always going to be more subtle and complex. In such circumstances the U.S. alliance allows us to maximise the options we have in any crisis that is likely to emerge. From Australia's point of view that results in defence, not dependence.

If we were to be involved in a conflict our first request to our ally would be for that which is easy to deliver-intelligence, diplomatic support, supply of vital parts and so on. An opponent wishing to escalate the conflict further, would have to consider the consequences of involving the U.S. more fully.
Although these questions are hypothetical in nature I raise them because they go to the heart of considerations which make defence self-reliance a realistic policy.

More concretely, the alliance provides immediate benefits in the influence it gives us in the arms control process and the contribution we are able to make to deterrence through our co-hosting of the joint facilities.

Another advantage Australia derives from our relationship with the U.S. is that we have access to technology, equipment and intelligence that would otherwise be unavailable to us. Consequently Australia is able to maintain a level of defence capability that enables us to realistically aim for defence self-reliance, and at a cost that is acceptable to peacetime governments facing periods of economic stringency.

This Government realises that a positive contribution to regional security is an essential part of our contribution to the Western alliance. Consequently the White Paper focuses attention on the region of our northern approaches and to the south-west Pacific area. As a result of this emphasis Australia supports defence co-operation activities with regional countries which share a similar strategic outlook.

As I announced in February this year, this Government now gives defence co-operation with our neighbours in the South Pacific the same priority as that given to our older and more substantial defence relations with the nations of South East Asia. This co-operation is being mainly directed towards assisting with the maritime surveillance of their exclusive economic zones.

In the current year, additional resources will be devoted to this assistance, principally the Pacific patrol boat project, development of national surveillance centres, RAAF long range maritime patrols, and RAN ship deployments.
The estimated cost for the defence co-operation program in 1987-88 is $58.3m. This represents an increase of $3.7m on last years expenditure.

Through our involvement in the defence co-operation program and through the continued consultations and contacts with military and defence officials from nations within our region, Australia is able to actively promote shared strategic concerns and contribute to developing regional stability.
This, in the long run, is the best form of self-defence.

I turn now to the area of improved efficiency. It is apparent that the pursuit of improved efficiency and productivity is a considerable challenge in an organisation as diverse and complex as defence. At the same time, because of the extent of the community's resources we consume, there are major benefits both to the defence area itself and to the community at large if we can improve our capacity to meet our objectives in a more cost effective fashion. I see it as a major task to stimulate an appreciation of the importance of achieving the best possible value for expenditure of the defence dollar.

The defence organisation is undergoing a period of rationalisation to tailor the organisation to meet the economic and strategic realities of the 1980s and the future. This is not a `cutting for cutting's sake' program but a responsible and orderly process of adjustment that makes it possible to contain defence outlay while building up defence capability.

More efficient management will mean that resources will be shifted to where they are needed-to the sharp end. A leaner, more streamlined organisation will be created. As the organisation is trimmed, so costs will be trimmed-thus releasing more of the defence dollar to increase combat effectiveness.

To this end, the Department of Defence has instituted a management improvement plan that has identified and set in train substantial changes to its structure aimed at improving its corporate management and the drive for greater efficiency.

We are currently spending in the order of $2 billion per annum on new facilities and equipment. We are presently managing some 140 different capital equipment and facilities projects, each costing more than $5 million.

Defence capital project management is marked on the whole by high investment, high risk, technical complexity and the potential for international collaboration. Managing the procurement of major capital equipment therefore presents the project manager with many challenges not shared by his or her contemporaries in other areas of management.

Defence will continue to place a high priority on the training of project staff with continuing in-house training on all aspects of the procurement process, and by the establishment in 1988 of a masters degree program in capital project management at a tertiary institution.

New demands for civil manpower are being generated at a time when the Government is conscious of the need to keep tight control over the numbers of personnel in public employment. A revised approach to manpower is being developed as part of the five-year defence program. The proposed strategy includes the following elements.
We will meet the Government's `across the board' efficiency dividend. Three per cent of the 3.75 civil manpower reduction required over the next three years will be achieved in this financial year.
We will continue a vigorous program of rationalisation of the workforce in the defence dockyards and production establishments.
A high percentage of the manpower savings achieved in the Office of Defence Production and elsewhere in Defence will be used to strengthen high priority areas requiring additional staffing.

We will pursue a program of conversion of some service posts to civilian ones using some of the civilian savings achieved from elsewhere, so as to release highly-trained service personnel for redeployment in accordance with Defence Force priorities. At the same time, there will be a cut of more than 1,300-to 38,369-in the approved average staffing level for civilians.

And we will further develop our capacity to meet our existing and new commitments by a vigorous program of management improvement based reviews and studies, which will include the rationalisation of functions and the contracting out of certain activities.
As the scope exists for overall productivity improvement in the use of our personnel resources, manpower and management arrangements will be major preoccupations over the next 2 to 3 years.

Specific measures are being addressed across the entire organisation. The rationalisation of the work force in the Office of Defence Production, while achieving a better balance between the size of the work force and existing work load, is only partially complete and will be pursued rigorously over the next two years.

The Government Aircraft Factories have now been established as a government owned company. Williamstown Dockyard is being sold as a going concern as part of the rationalisation process. Restructuring of the munitions factories has resulted in more direct working hours from less people.

These rationalisation measures in the Office of Defence Production are being undertaken so that the extent of government subsidy to defence production establishments is reduced significantly and the funds saved are directed to other areas of defence priority.
A review of defence logistics is currently being undertaken. This is aimed at:
improving performance and effectiveness across the range of logistics functions,
significantly reducing costs,
reducing requirements for service manpower and thus making manpower available for other ADF priorities,
rationalising, to the greatest possible extent, property holdings falling within the defence portfolio,
rationalising systems and approaches to logistics,
putting authority closer to the point of action.
The longer term benefits and savings will be considerable.
I expect rapid progress from civilian and service management towards changing some traditional approaches to defence logistics. There will in future be greater focus on:
cost consciousness,
greater authority being vested in individual service offices closer to the point of action (together with greater accountability for decisions actually made),
introduction of more commercial approaches including the provision of some services by contractors.
The heavy burden of day to day logistics works will continue during 1987-88. For example:
Preliminary work on the basing of half of the fleet at Garden Island in Western Australia will continue,
Work is underway to develop a bare base airfield on the Cape York Peninsula,
Planning is well advanced on facilities associated with the move of the 2 Cavalry Regiment to the Northern Territory,
New measures to merit better management of information throughout the department will be introduced,
The development of a modern, common-core computer based supply system will continue,
Logistic support arrangements with other countries in South East Asia and the south-west Pacific region will continue to be developed.

Recent months have also seen major initiatives for management improvement within the services. Efficiency measures are to be effected across the board and the services are playing their part in ensuring that the defence dollar is wisely spent. It is indeed very much in the interests of every member of the Defence Force because the savings mean more defence capability not less. This equation is unprecedented in Australia's history.

The new personnel resource strategy for the Defence Force outlined in the White Paper will be implemented in 1988. Part of this important initiative involves moving away from undue emphasis on the strength of the Defence Force on a particular day each year and towards the balancing of ongoing activities, recruitment and sepa-rations to produce an average strength over the year.

More significantly, the new strategy identifies separate average staffing levels for the year for an operational force of trained personnel, and for a training force comprising personnel undergoing pre-employment training. When higher than normal separation rates are experienced, the training force will be supplemented to maintain the level and capacity of the trained force.

These concepts will allow the strength of the training force to rise and fall in parallel with variations in separation rates while maintaining the trained force at the strength necessary to meet the objectives set for it by Government.

The manpower resource available to the ADF in 1987-88 will provide an operational force with an average strength of some 63,000 trained personnel supported by a training force of some 7,000 and active reserve forces of 30,800. The planned average regular strengths for 1987-88 are: Navy 15,657; Army 31,746; Air Force 22,612.
This strategy will improve the management of defence manpower by allowing service chiefs to allocate resources in a clear and defined manner.

In this statement I have highlighted the main features of the defence budget and shown how it is tailored to meet the real defence needs of Australia. The significance of this budget is that it shows what can be achieved in improving defence capability when the Go-vernment gives clear guidance, sound strategy and defined priorities.

This budget is not a formula for less defence, but a re-ordering of practices and procedures designed to get the utmost benefit for the taxpayer's dollar that will provide dividends through to the start of the 21st century.

The 1976 White Paper mooted the notion of self-reliance but failed to grapple with the specifics-that is, the force structure necessary for such a defence strategy. And even that germ of an idea was not allowed to come to fruition because of the coalition Government's failure to implement any measures that would have given this country a self-reliant defence policy.

Lance Barnard began the process of re-thinking Australia's real defence needs some 15 years ago and once again it is a Labor Government that has brought that period of review to a close. A revolution in defence planning and in shaping defence capability means that this Government is re-shaping the Defence Force for the 21st century and not leaving it and the Defence Force with the inappropriate legacy of the 1960s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This post-Budget statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) indicates that the Minister and his Government are completely out of touch with the military requirements of the late twentieth century, and completely out of touch with developments which are taking place worldwide. I am certain that they are following the line that their overseers in the United States of America lay down for them. It is obvious, in looking at this paper, that that is the case. On the first page the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Government believes in a self-reliant defence of Australia. It believes that our people should know that this is possible, that Australia can do it, can afford to do it, and must do it.

Excellent, good idea; self-reliance and an independent Australia is a wonderful idea. But are we independent? Of course not. Look at our equipment purchases. They do not suit our requirements; they suit the requirements of the United States. That is why we have FA18s and nuclear capable frigates. We are equipping ourselves, at great expense to the taxpayers, with American equipment to fight an American war with nuclear weapons. That is the US strategy, and for those who doubt it, let us look at what Captain Linton F. Brooks, a US National Security Council member, says in the recent edition of the proceedings of the US Naval Institute. He says that the American naval or maritime strategy is a nuclear strategy. It involves the horizontal escalation of any conventional war-in Korea, Europe or anywhere else-into a nuclear war. It has a policy of striking against Soviet ballistic missile submarines. Australia is involved in that in two ways. First, we have nuclear capable aircraft and ships and, secondly, we have the base at the North West Cape, which would give the signal for such strike action. We are implicated in all of that. It does not defend us in any way. In fact, it escalates the possibility of nuclear war and puts us right in the big league of nuclear warfare.

There are some significant statements on page 19 of the Minister's statement concerning the `joint facilities'. It is interesting that the Hawke conservative Government simply does not have enough guts to admit that these are US bases. The US knows that they are US bases and it refers to them as such. But our Government is cute. It does not want to admit that they are US bases; it calls them the `joint facilities'. It states:

More concretely, the alliance provides immediate benefits in the influence it gives us in the arms control process and the contribution we are able to make to deterrence through our co-hosting of the joint facilities.

Somehow we have been sold this idea-although not many really believe it-that these bases are used for verification, and thus for peace. Is the North West Cape used for verification? Of course not; it is a communications base. It transmits information to US nuclear submarines. What about Pine Gap? Is it used for verification? Not really. Pine Gap is an intelligence gathering operation for the Central Intelligence Agency. It gathers intelligence all right, but it is not used for verification. What about Nurrungar? Well, it is not used for verification either. It is actually the first step in a star wars system. It operates infra-red detecting satellites. In terms of satellite technology, what we use for verification are not geostationary satellites, monitored from Australia, but polar orbiting satellites which pass over the United States and can release their information directly to the United States or any of its territories. Therefore, these bases are not used for verification. In addition, a development which is now taking place and which is apparently unknown to our Government is that the Soviets and the Americans are close to an agreement on on-site visitation of their nuclear facilities. If we have people standing around and looking at these facilities, any verification role that might exist in Australia-and I do not believe there is any-will be redundant. The truth, which everyone has accepted, although I do not think we really realise the ramifications-we have not thought it through-and which even our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has admitted, is that the bases make us nuclear targets. So, far from being a nuclear umbrella, they are a nuclear lightning-rod.

Nothing in this statement gives us any inkling of who the enemy is. If we are to have a defence program, the Government ought to outline who the enemy is, but there is no such outline. We do not know who the enemy is. It is not spelt out in this paper. In fact, the Government is pretty coy about the whole thing in general. Is it perhaps the Soviets? Are the Russians the enemy? Do they covet our territory? Whilst they might come after the US bases on our soil or after any nuclear powered or armed ships of the US fleet in our harbours, they are not our enemy and they do not covet our territory. Even if they did, does anyone in this chamber or in this Government think they have the capability of launching an amphibious assault on Australia when they can barely maintain an operation in Afghanistan which entails only taking trucks across the Soviet border? It is patently foolish to believe that the Soviets could be a military threat to us.

What about the Japanese? Incidentally, as we have said over and over again, the ANZUS Treaty was set up in the 1950s to protect us from the Japanese. The Japanese were about to re-arm. Australia and New Zealand were quite nervous about this, and they talked the United States into a treaty to protect them from the Japanese. Are the Japanese our enemy? No. They own the company. They get everything they want here. They do not have to occupy it. They have created their great dream for a co-prosperity sphere in the Pacific. They have actually completed their program here. They are not our military enemy. So who is the enemy?

The political awareness shown by politicians not only in Australia but around the north Atlantic area is interesting. I recently returned from a delegation to the meeting of the North Atlantic Assembly in Oslo, which was a meeting of politicians involved in the countries which make up the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO). In the one short session devoted to the Pacific, we-the Australians and the Japanese-were lectured by a number of highly placed English lords. The Japanese were lectured on the subject that they should re-arm, that they were not spending enough on armaments-only 1.5 per cent of their gross national product. They were told that they should re-arm. I think that the Japanese were polite enough not to show their surprise and disgust at that. But it is the thinking of politicians that we must re-arm constantly. In fact, there is a movement in the other direction which is not reflected in this statement or any other statement by this Government. The fact is that disarmament is proceeding apace.

We have heard of the intermediate range nuclear forces (INF) negotiations, which will come to fruition. There will be a reduction in those forces. There will also be a reduction in the strategic nuclear weapons forces. This is very threatening to the defence establishment, and it was very threatening to NATO. During the North Atlantic Assembly meeting, we were told over and over again that we must guard against disarmament. There was a dual message: we must guard against disarmament, but if it happened, it would happen because we had a lot of weapons and it could not be in any way attributed to the activities of the peace movement-which, of course, is absolutely false. It was the peace movement that brought about the disarmament negotiations in the first place.

These military planning establishments fear the outbreak of peace. They worry about conventional warfare. They say, `If we lose our nuclear deterrents, we will need more conventional forces'. Incidentally, while I was in Brussels being briefed by the NATO staff in their headquarters, we were told by Mr Merrill Walters, the NATO Director of Nuclear Planning, and a United States colonel named G. R. Akam that NATO's flexible response depended on nuclear weapons. Their opinion was that a nuclear war could be limited and winnable. A limited and winnable nuclear war! I asked these military planners, `How do you limit it?' They said, `We can do that. We have ways'. I do not believe that they have ways. This is the sort of thinking that is reflected in this defence statement.

But there is a change taking place. In East Berlin on 28 and 29 May this year, the Warsaw Pact nations got together and decided on a policy of military sufficiency. This reflects the Gorbachev line of reduction of nuclear weapons; but he is also going for a reduction in the number of conventional weapons. One may be sceptical as to his motives, but if one looks closely one will see that they are purely economic. One does not have to look any further than that. It takes a lot of money to maintain a large conventional force; it takes a lot of money to maintain nuclear weapons. He would like to cut back. Military sufficiency, in the Warsaw Pact lexicon, means a defensive posture-a posture in which they maintain enough troops and enough weaponry to repel an attack, but do not intend to launch one.

This has massive ramifications for Europe. There are 450,000 allied troops on the ground in Europe. If the Warsaw Pact starts to pull back its troops, these troops will also be pulled out. Having spent a month in Europe, I know that the Europeans are universally sick and tired of being in the main area of potential nuclear conflict. They want out. People around the world are saying, `Enough. Enough of this nonsense of the military planners controlling our future. It is time for the people to take over'. And the people are taking over.

What should we be doing? We should be taking cognisance of the onrushing advent of world peace, at least in a super-power sense. It is foolish for us to ally ourselves as closely as we are with the nuclear capability of the United States when, in fact, the United States will not help us in any foreseeable conflict in the future. The only potential enemy that anyone has been able to identify in this area is Indonesia. I am not saying that we shall be going to war with Indonesia, but defence analysts have said that Indonesia is our only potential enemy. Can these forces that we now have help us in a battle with Indonesia? No; not much. Can we count on the United States to come to our aid in any battle with Indonesia? No, we cannot. Certainly, under ANZUS the Americans are not required to. They are required to hold consultations with us. They did not step in in the 1960s when Indonesia moved into West Irian, and they would not step in in a battle with Indonesia. Why would they not step in? Because of their own interests in Indonesia, the oil and the tin, and the fact that they do not want to interfere with Indonesia and perhaps allow Indonesia to become communist-led. They will not come and help us.

Many people say, `Well, the Americans helped us in the battle of the Coral Sea'. But that was not merely because they wanted to help Australia; they needed to use Australia for a base. It was not pure altruism. Certainly, they like Australians; but as we have seen in the wheat deals and other agricultural happenings in the United States, when it comes to United States interests, they come first. United States political interests take precedence over any friendship with any other nation, including Australia.

What do we need? We need to divert our defence budget away from all these nice, expensive toys for the boys that the Americans are selling us, to a more home-grown defence force which can actually defend Australia. What we have is skills in the bush. We need, perhaps, a highly mobile reserve force that can be mobilised quickly. We need the capability of transferring this force around the country. We do not have it at the moment. We need transport aircraft, close ground support aircraft and helicopters.

Then we need a defensive posture. Instead of using an offensive concept, in which we project our power by means of FA18s, F111s and over-the-horizon systems, all we really need is a defensive weaponry system. Our military planners have not yet learnt the lesson of the Falklands war. They are still going for big ships and big submarines. The lesson was that one $250,000 Exocet can sink any ship around. To launch an Exocet one does not need a very sophisticated platform. It can be launched from a shrimp trawler, an F27 aircraft, or almost anything. We should be more flexible in our acceptance and our use of modern weaponry. We now have shoulder-carried weapons which can knock out aeroplanes quite easily. It is a lot cheaper by far to have a defensive posture rather than an offensive posture. It takes far fewer troops and far less expenditure of money. But it takes a commitment to the idea that we will no longer simply furnish a back-up to the United States nuclear strategy.

We need to declare our independence from the United States, from any power on earth, and opt for a completely Australian-oriented defence strategy. We do not have it now. This Government does not recognise it. I only pray that, before it is too late, we do recognise it and we do take some steps to give ourselves true military defensive capability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The post-Budget statement on defence entitled `Defence Budget 1987-88' presented by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), who represents the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), is an empty, bombastic document. Parts of it are false and, in its general sense, it is totally misleading. It is totally misleading because it attempts to portray that the Australian defence forces are in good shape, that morale is high and that they have great capability. Nothing could be further from the truth. The defence forces today are facing a crisis of a magnitude that we have never before seen in peacetime in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence of Australia is the most important duty that a government faces. However, the post-Budget statement on defence contains parts that are false and it is bombastic and childishly party political. There is no place for party politics in the defence of this country. The problems that face us are common to the defence analysts of all political parties. The support of all Australians is required in working for a stable and secure country. Therefore, to indulge in the childishness in which the Minister for Defence indulges in the closing paragraphs of the statement is absolutely beneath contempt. While I am on the subject of contempt, I am sorry that Senator Sanders gets the opportunity to speak here when he is so incorrect factually in most of the nonsense he puts forward in the defence field.

The basic point of this document is that the Australian Labor Party is living up to its traditions. It treats the Australian defence forces with contempt and starves them financially. This document is an attempt to camouflage the savage cutting in funds that has taken place in the four and a bit years since this Government came to power. I would like to illustrate that by referring to a couple of points. The final five-year defence plan approved by the Fraser Government provided for an average rate of real growth in total defence outlays of 6.3 per cent for the period 1982-83 to 1986-87. When this Government came to power it revised that 6.3 per cent real growth figure down to 4.5 per cent. In the Government's May 1985 economic statement it cut the 4.5 per cent real growth down to 3.1 per cent. In the notorious May 1987 economic statement the growth rate was taken into a negative position. In other words, defence funds have been cut and they have been cut to a staggering degree-in the Minister's own words-of $1.5 billion. In the next three years $1,500m will be taken out of the defence vote. That reflects this Government's priorities in defence.

We have not only had funds cut back. At present, circumstances are such in regard to long term contracts-contracts which the Government inherited; it did not initiate them-for the purchase of the FA18 and frigates that the amount of money in the annual defence budget going to new capital equipment has almost doubled. Again, in the Fraser years of 1982-83, the percentage of government expenditure on capital equipment and defence was 17.4 per cent. By 1984-85 it had grown to 25.9 per cent. I have not seen the figures for this year, but probably close to 27 per cent or 28 per cent of the defence vote would be going to capital equipment. That approximately 10 per cent capital equipment increase to 27 per cent or 28 per cent in a roughly constant defence budget means that things such as training, conditions of service and operational readiness of the Services have suffered because the Government has not increased the vote, as it needed to do.

The facts of life are that a defence force and a defence capability are expensive. They cannot be bought on the cheap. The name of the game is to decide the priorities and to get those priorities as efficiently as possible. The budget cutting has had an absolutely catastrophic effect on morale.

Despite what the Minister, with his adulation of equipment, is always saying, there is no more important factor in defence than the men and women who wear the uniform of the Australian defence services. They have been utterly devastated by the contempt of this Government for their conditions of service. If we accept the Minister's assessment in the defence paper of a total permanent strength of 63,000 men and women in the Australian defence forces, since Labor came to power we have seen a resignation figure in excess of 33,000 men and women, which represents over half the personnel. Those service people who have left are middle ranking officers in the mature part of their service. At great expense to the Commonwealth they have been trained in the various arms of the Services. We have lost senior non-commissioned officers. When we start losing senior NCOs we pay a grievous price. I regard those WO1s, and their equivalents in the Navy and Air Force, as the finest members of the Australian community. They are mature, sensible and enormously capable people who simply cannot be replaced in a hurry. These senior NCOs represent the heart of any service. They are leaving in their droves. They are leaving because, for them, service in uniform under this Government is utterly pointless.

We are also losing technicians. These are people who serve in the three armed Services out of a sense of commitment to their country, knowing full well that as electronic engineers and technicians in civilian life they could earn two or three times the amount they presently earn. These people are happy to work for their country while they feel it is all worth while. But they know now that it is not worth while, and they are leaving.

Senator Messner raised the matter of the resignation of pilots. We are facing a scandalous situation here. For 20 years the loss rate of pilots from the Royal Australian Air Force averaged 42 pilots a year. In the last three years of the Labor Government we have seen 60, 70 and 107 resignations of pilots from the Royal Australian Air Force. In the three months of this financial year, that is in July, August and September, between 60 and 70 pilots have resigned or have applied to resign. We simply will not have any pilots in the Air Force at the rate we are going. This great Service, this very professional air force, simply cannot operate at present because of the loss of pilots.

We have three fighter squadrons, one strike squadron and, in support, a training squadron with a reconnaissance capability in No. 6 squadron. We have No. 10 and No. 11 squadrons, the maritime reconnaissance squadrons; we have two C130 transport squadrons and a Caribou squadron. We have 10 squadrons in operational command. Probably we have a pool on strength of 15 pilots in most of those squadrons at any time. That represents 150 pilots. However, we lost 107 pilots last year. I know that there are probably 200 or 300 other pilots in the Air Force pushing desks, but they are not operational. They are people who have gone through the active flying part of their lives. They are senior officers and people in administrative roles.

The cost to Australia of all of this is catastrophic. It cannot be defended. Our first line of defence is the air. We have lost the people in whom we have invested millions of dollars in training. Probably it costs $2m or $3m to train a pilot. They cannot be replaced overnight. The tragedy is that we are now in a position in which the capabilities of the Australian Defence Force have been lost, probably for a generation-for 10 or 15 years-because we have lost key personnel. We cannot train them overnight. We cannot build up the doctrine and the capability the Defence Force must have if it is to be ready for instant service.

The training cost of all this is enormous. We are in a position of being short of money and people. However, because of the very high rate of resignations we have to devote an undue percentage of the defence forces to training. Therefore we have fewer personnel available for an operational role and we have a greatly increased budgetary cost. It is all so silly. All it needed was a little more money. Let us look, for example, at something that the Air Force had to do in relation to pilots. Last year the defence forces had to pay $39m in fringe benefits tax. Could anything be more absurd than a government department having to pay fringe benefits tax? Yet the defence forces lost $39m from their budget. If that had gone into supplementing the pilots' incomes we would have retained 90 per cent of those pilots. It probably would only have needed a few thousand dollars a year in the form of a decent flying allowance for these people to keep them in the Services, and we would not have had any trouble.

On page 2 of today's Australian a new Minister, Mrs Kelly, is quoted as saying that the defence forces had to accept the fact that high wastage rates were good for morale. I do not know Mrs Kelly, but she must be as silly as Senator Ryan. To say that high wastage rates are good for morale is just as silly as Mr Hayden saying in the early days of the Hawke Government that inflation is good for us because our house is worth more or Mr Whitlam saying, when he was spending all the money we had in foreign reserves, `We do not need foreign reserves. They mean nothing to us'. It is no wonder the Services are in total despair when a Minister responsible for them says that high wastage rates are good for morale.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a nonsense.

—It is absolute nonsense. I think it is criminal incompetence to have such people in a ministerial position dealing with departments about which they simply know nothing. Let me turn to the statement. I do not want to go through it in detail; it does not justify that. On page 5 of the Minister's speech he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The central message of this defence budget is that the White Paper is on track and will stay on track.
On the previous page he stated:
I am pleased to be able to report to the Parliament that the ADF is responding very well.

The Australian Defence Force is responding so well that it is voting with its feet. Under this Government we are experiencing huge and unparalleled resignations from the Services. The central message of this defence budget that the White Paper is on track and will stay on track is arrant nonsense. Nothing could be further from the truth. The White Paper was a good paper because it was prepared by professionals, unlike the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities which was characterised by its professional vacuity. The White Paper demands a certain minimal level of support in a budgetary way and it simply has not had it. Instead of the defence vote getting an increase of about 3 per cent per year in real terms, which is the bare minimum needed to support the White Paper's predictions, it will be cut by $1,500m over the next few years.

In the next part of the Minister's speech he deals with equipment. That section is padded out. Some of his claims are quite incorrect. He talked about the Jindalee project. This Government has an obsession with the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar system, and it has an obsession with it because it seems a cheap option for satisfying the essential requirement of knowing who is coming and going around the northern half of Australia. That is an absolutely fundamental requirement, but Jindalee will not satisfy it.

Jindalee is a great development. Over-the-horizon radars go back almost to the dawn of radar, certainly to the late 1940s. I do not want to go through the technicalities of it, but Jindalee is still in its development phase. It probably needs five to 10 years of work because the great difficulty with it is the software programs and computer systems which analyse the signals that come back. In no sense will Jindalee, even when it is fully developed, be an effective surveillance system. It is a very coarse and crude system. It will tell us in certain conditions that someone is out there; it will not tell us in all conditions that someone is out there, and it certainly will not identify people, whether they be friend or foe. Nor will it identify what they are doing. We have to follow up the warnings and look at them in detail.

Other systems have to be provided, such as an airborne early warning system. If the Government had not had the hide to take $39m off the Department of Defence last year with the fringe benefits tax, we could have had one airborne early warning aircraft. The Government is not concerned with knowing who comes into this country.

I do not wish to take much more of the time of the Senate in going through this statement, but there is not a word in it about the bloated number of public servants in the Department of Defence and the effect that that is having by eating up money which should be going into operational capability, and the fact that these people second guess the professionals in the defence service. A classic example of this is the decision on the PC9-the new basic trainer for the Royal Australian Air Force-to which the Minister refers in his statement. The Air Force wanted the PC7, which was a much cheaper aircraft and perfectly adequate for the role of a trainer. However, for some reason the civilians-this was established at an Estimates committee hearing-wanted the more sophisticated PC9. The cost of the PC9 is about $1.5m to $1.7m, as against $700,000 for the PC7. Again, if the difference in that contract money had been paid as a flying bonus for the Air Force, we would not have lost the huge number of pilots we have. The Minister made the following statement about the PC9:

A new training aircraft, the PC9, is being built in Australia for the Air Force. It is the best basic trainer aircraft in the world, and it will allow the Air Force new, more flexible and more economical training programs.

That is wrong. The PC9 is probably the most expensive training aircraft in the world and its very expense imposes very high costs on the Air Force. It will not provide a more economical system of training. We have here an aircraft whose performance is better than that of a World War II fighter. It is better than that of a Mustang or a Spitfire. We cannot take an 18-year-old who has never flown and put him in an aircraft which has those capabilities, and which costs nearly $2m, and say, `Go and teach yourself to fly'. It does not happen that way. So we will have to have a basic trainer inserted below this one, and it was not the Air Force's intention to have a basic trainer below the alleged basic trainer replacement. So we have the cost of that, and we also have the cost of operating the PC9. It is a quite sophisticated aeroplane, though it really is nothing more than a training aeroplane-it has a huge engine, and its operating costs on an hourly basis are very high. Again that money has to come out of the defence vote. I would argue that we do not need that capability in a training role.

I come back to the point at which I started. There is nothing in this statement which refers to Public Service interference in the Department of Defence. The failure of this Government is to recognise that the people in the Australian defence forces are human beings. The only statement Minister Beazley ever makes is that he is buying this bit of equipment or is looking at that bit of equipment. He is obsessed with toys. He has no concept that there are human beings involved who need to be supported, who need to be made to feel that they are doing a worthwhile job. These are great Australians. They are genuine patriots who are prepared to suffer all sorts of hardships and disabilities to serve the defence of this country and to keep all the rest of us safely in our beds at night. They are not people who want to be the high income earners of the Australian community. They are prepared to accept lower salaries, lower returns and all the rest of it if they feel they are doing a worthwhile job. But all they get from this Labor Government is endless kicks and the cutting of their conditions. The Government is now cutting their housing grant when they end their service. When service personnel apply for a reasonable increase in their field allowances and so on they are cut back by the appeal court.

The civilian component of the Department of Defence, secure in its luxury at Russell Hill, is arguing, against the service personnel, for lower standards and is saying, `No, these fellows don't need that allowance increase'. At the end of the day they get someone such as Mr Beazley or Mrs Kelly as their ministerial representation. Even Helen Mayer, a failed House of Representatives candidate, is somehow getting into the loop as a consultant for the Department. No wonder service personnel are leaving; no wonder they are seeking careers outside the Australian defence forces. Today we have a crisis in the Australian Defence Force and this statement in no way recognises the situation that we are in. At best, it is a pathetic effort of self-deception; at worst it is a total sellout of Australia's defence for some damned disarmament document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 8 October 1987, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs reports to the Senate the Australia Card Bill 1986 (No. 3). I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs to be clearly understood that, although this motion formally notifies the Senate that the reference of matters regarding the Australia Card to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee on 23 September has now been dealt with, and, by virtue of a resolution passed in the Senate yesterday, the Committee is indicating that it has discharged its responsibility as far as that resolution is concerned, nevertheless yesterday the Senate also resolved to refer to the Committee certain ongoing matters connected with the Australia Card, with the principles which were behind the establishment of the Australia Card in the first instance. That Committee will now be looking at a number of matters, including the future of the proposed births, deaths and marriages register in the event of the failure of any of the States to assist with the provision of information; the extent to which new crackdowns on welfare cheating and tax fraud and new upgraded computer systems have obviated the original need for the system; the response to reports from the Australian Federal Police and the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth; the cost issues; the effectiveness of the Data Protection Agency; the need for privacy legislation; the extent of personal data held on Australian citizens by government departments and agencies; the security of the holding and transmission of that data; various questions on penalties and material available from overseas; and the usefulness of any card numbering system in achieving the objectives of reducing the extent of the cash economy, organised crime and large scale tax evasion and welfare fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I think it important to place on the record that, although the Australia Card reference of 23 September has now been discharged and by this report brought back to the Senate, and although the Australia Card legislation-the actual Bill-has been withdrawn from Parliament by resolution yesterday, nevertheless the Australia Card Bill, although gone, is not forgotten. The ongoing inquiry that will be undertaken by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee will allow people to make submissions to the Committee on those issues which were of concern during the course of the debate about the original Australia Card legislation. I would certainly hope, as do all members of the Opposition, that people in the community who have a concern about the issues raised, those of privacy, cost, security of data, tax evasion, welfare fraud, organised crime and all the other aspects, will understand that they will be in a position to make submissions to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, to seek to appear as witnesses before the new inquiry and to seek to participate in the activities of that investigation, which has to report back to the Senate by 1 May 1988.

Therefore, I simply wanted to put on record that, although it appears, if one simply looks at the report, which is to be ordered to be printed, that the Australia Card legislation has been discharged from the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, that refers only to the reference given on 23 September, and that Committee is now required to produce a much more detailed report on the issues which were behind the introduction of the Australia Card legislation in the first place. I know that the Committee will undertake that task with some enthusiasm. I have noted the muted excitement with which the Chairman and other Australian Labor Party members of the Committee have accepted the reference being made to them. I know the considerable interest with which the senators on this side who will be the Opposition's representatives on that Committee-Senators Alston, Hill and Stone-are looking forward to undertaking that task. I am sure that, when the Committee reports on 1 May 1988, it will be making it abundantly clear that the reasons that the Government put forward for introducing the Australia Card in the first place are once again shown to be false and specious. The Government's cost estimates were wildly out--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The motion before the Chair is that the report of the Committee should be printed. I have allowed you some latitude to develop your argument, Senator Puplick, but now you are going too far. You should wind your remarks up or confine them to the motion that the report be printed.

—You are quite right, Mr Deputy President, to say that the motion before us is that the report be printed, and I welcome the printing of this report, which discharges the obligation given to the Senate Committee on the first occasion. I simply reiterate the point that this matter is no longer to be thought of simply as having been discharged permanently from the attention of the Senate. The Committee which will undertake the investigation and report on 1 May will have all these other things before it and undoubtedly will produce, as the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee of the Senate always has, an absolutely outstanding report which will explore fully all the issues, conclude that the original Australia Card legislation was unnecessary and demonstrate that future legislation will be equally unnecessary.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:

1. That the Senate concurs in the Resolution transmitted to the Senate by Message No. 6 of the House of Representatives relating to the appointment of a Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.
2. That the provisions of the resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
