SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very keen to support this motion, especially as, only this morning, we had before us from the Government a paper which revealed the real necessity for an active Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The disappointing effort made in this Parliament by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in his statement `Defence Budget'-simply a snow job-is a clear indication of why we need parliamentary committees of energy and vigilance. The Government and the Minister have talked loud and long about what they will do for defence. When it comes to the point, as my colleagues Senator Messner and Senator MacGibbon have said, the Government is just not prepared to front up with the money.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be the first to agree that the Department of Defence needs to encourage efficiency and a good use of resources. In many ways, especially in the past, the resources have not been used to the best advantage and there has been waste of various kinds. The Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and then the White Paper led us to hope that things would be better in the future. The Minister for Defence was loud in his claims that this Government would do the right thing by the defence of this country. Yet, in the very first Budget after his White Paper we find a real cut of one per cent in the defence vote. I remember very clearly the criticism by the Australian Labor Party of the former Fraser Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point or order. I know that Senator Newman was perhaps upset at the fact that with the intervention of these formal matters she was unable to make her remarks on the post-Budget statement by the Minister for Defence. I understand that but I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to make sure that her remarks are devoted to the setting up of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and that she is not using this occasion to make the remarks she might have otherwise made if the debate had not been interrupted.

—Senator Newman, so far your remarks have been in order but I was listening to them with some concern. The motion is a formal one to set up a committee. It would be appropriate to discuss in general terms the desirability of having such a committee, but any specific matters of current defence policy would be beyond the scope of this motion before the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I accept the ruling, of course. I hope that this Joint Committee will look at a number of matters which were referred to in the Minister's statement. He has referred to a number of equipment matters. I do not intend to hold up the business of the Senate for an undue time today. I hope the Committee will look at such things as whether we should have a navy that can only sit around the coast of Australia and that cannot protect our sea lanes of communication.
—I just ask you, Mr Deputy President, to consider your previous remarks and indicate whether the honourable senator is straying beyond the terms of the motion.

—Mr Deputy President, the Minister for Justice has alleged certain reasons why Senator Newman is making a speech. He does not know why she is making a speech; he only knows the subject which she is addressing. The subject before the chamber is the consideration of message No. 6, the appointment of a joint foreign affairs, defence and trade committee. Senator Newman, as you so rightly pointed out, is addressing that subject-the appointment of a committee. If the Minister for Justice wants to continue along the path he is taking, he may do so, but the rest of the business for today will be delayed by other tactics. I suggest that the Minister for Justice allow Senator Newman to get on and make her speech. Then we can get on with the business of the day.
—I am not going to be threatened by you.

—On the point of order raised by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, I repeat my earlier ruling that Senator Newman is entitled to discuss the desirability of a joint foreign affairs, defence and trade committee being set up. She is entitled to discuss in general terms what the role of such a committee should be. She is not entitled, for instance, to discuss the defence statement recently tabled by the Minister, except in general terms as far as it affects the workings of the joint committee.

—I hope that this Committee will look at some of the problems associated with the Defence White Paper, the Dibb Review, an assessment as to how far out our ships should go, what capacity our strike planes should have, and what having our Army in the north will do to logistic support. I hope that the Committee will be able to look at those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope very seriously that this Committee will look at the appalling separation rates in our defence forces, which my colleagues have referred to earlier this morning, and will act when it is made aware of the fact that Army wives are going to public meetings. This fact was set out in the Telegraph newspaper this morning. It is unheard of for them to be articulate in the public arena. They make up a most conservative and quiet community but their tempers are roused. I hope the Committee will look at what this Government has done to the defence service home loans scheme and to Defence Force retirement and death benefits.

There is not sufficient time for me to explain all the other areas that I feel the Committee should look at. But it took two weeks for us to get 150 men off the coast of Fiji, with no fire and air support. A committee should look as just what that means in terms of our ability to rescue Australians who are off the coast of Australia. What would have happened in Fiji if those forces had met resistance? These are very serious questions about our ability to protect our citizens and our sea lanes of communication. It is appropriate that these areas be looked at by a major parliamentary committee. If the Government is not prepared to look at these matters, as is clearly evident by the debate earlier today on the Minister's statement-it is a complete and utter snow job-parliamentary committees must take that watch-dog role. The way the Government has been prepared to mouth the right things and not back that up with money is not good enough. I know that Senator Tate is concerned that I should canvass these views but they have to be made public. This Government is failing the citizens of Australia in the most important job any national government can do; that is, protecting the nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I support the motion moved by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I assume that he is referring to two documents, including the modification to message No. 7 that came from the House of Representatives, because that modification increases the membership of the proposed committee from eight to 10.
—That is the correct motion, Senator Short. It is headed `Substitute copy'.

—The Opposition welcomes this motion for a variety of reasons. First, we welcome the change from the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which has existed in recent years, to the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters. This reflects two things. First, it reflects the very valuable work that the Joint Select Committee did, particularly in 1983, when it produced the most comprehensive report which, to my knowledge, has ever been done on electoral reform issues in Australia. That report led to fundamental changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1984-changes which brought in such matters as public funding of elections and a variety of other quite fundamental alterations. The Select Committee also produced a valuable report following the 1984 election which reviewed the changes that had been introduced prior to that election. This was a practical review to see how the changes worked. Secondly, the translation of the Select Committee into a standing committee not only reflects the importance of the work that the Joint Select Committee has done but also reflects the continuing importance of electoral matters to this House and to the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference of the proposed Joint Committee are:
To inquire into and report on such matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration, as may be referred to it by either House of the Parliament or by a Minister.

As I interpret those terms of reference, and I hope this is how the Parliament will interpret them, they are sufficiently broad to encompass all the types of electoral matters that were considered by the previous Joint Select Committee because, with the passage of time-and it is four or five years since those changes were recommended by the earlier Select Committee and implemented-there is a need for continuing review of some of their fundamental bases. For example, I think we need to have another look at the whole question of public funding. There is a difference of view between the two sides of this chamber about the desirability of public funding. We in the Liberal Party of Australia have made no secret of our opposition to it in the past and that is something we should have a look at in the future-as a party and as a Parliament.

Another issue that we have not looked at for a long time is the whole question of compulsory versus voluntary voting in the Australian system. I am not necessarily advocating a change from compulsory to voluntary voting, although I personally have some sympathy with that point of view, but I think these are issues which should be looked at in an evolving democracy. I hope that these considerations will be debated and reviewed by a committee such as the one we are now establishing.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been talking about extending the referendum to include an extension of the parliamentary term. Again, I would hope that that matter would be an issue for this Committee. If we are to have worthwhile, ongoing and desirable reform of electoral issues the support of all major parties will be needed, particularly if referenda are involved; otherwise there is no way in the world those referenda proposals will be passed. I hope that this Joint Committee will provide a forum for rational, intelligent and all-party-not necessarily bipartisan-consideration of some of these issues. We welcome the establishment of this Joint Committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate. We agree with its proposed membership and its terms of reference. We look forward to participating in a constructive way in its operations in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion. I have been approached to serve on the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters and I look forward to being able to participate in its work. When I was State Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia I was asked to give evidence before the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in 1983-84 on the matters it was then considering. I believe that the Joint Committee's recommendations, which were adopted by the Parliament, were some of the most significant reforms on electoral matters at the Federal level in this country's history. I believe that the commitment to establish clearly in legislation one vote one value was an extremely important measure. I also believe that, despite some people in the community having queries about it and opposing it, public funding was a very important reform. The new Joint Committee will have to look not only at the operation of public funding, as it has been now for two elections, but also at wider issues-that is, the cost of elections.

SPEECH.PARA: As a former State Secretary of the Labor Party in South Australia I am fully aware of the horrendous problems that all political parties-whether they be Labor, Liberal, Democrat or one of the minor parties-have about running effective campaigns and in respect of the money needed. There is now a case emerging for limits to the amount of expenditure, particularly in relation to the electronic media. Television and radio costs-particularly television-are escalating not at an arithmetic rate but at a geometric progression. That is a matter that is going to affect the operation of democracy in this country-when the ability of political parties to put their platform before the people is affected by their ability to get money. It is quite legitimate for this Committee to investigate ways of limiting the amounts of money expended. I do not know whether it is constitutionally possible to do it in a way which covers every possible avenue, but it certainly is one that I want to take up when I am on the Committee.

I also believe that in the area of electoral reform we have a further need in this country to debate, argue and commit the Australian community to the concept of equality of representation. It is well known in this chamber that there are still three States that have, in some form or another, what one would call `gerrymandered electorates', some form of limited franchise or malapportionment of boundaries. There is the well-known case in Queensland, the Western Australian situation and there are some queries about the upper House in Tasmania. The Joint Standing Committee, as a permanent committee, has an obligation to educate the Australian people about the fact that if one wants democracy in this country all people must be treated equally in their opportunity to participate in voting and electing. I hope that as a matter of urgency the Committee can deal with the particular problems in those States and with the recent events in Queensland, where there have been amazing allegations of corruption in the police force. I always remember the then Premier of South Australia, Don Dunstan, who fought against the gerrymander in South Australia for about 20 years, saying, `You only get good, clean, honest government when you have good, clean, honest electoral systems where it is known that if 51 per cent of the people vote for a party that party will form the government. If a government believes that it can be elected, irrespective of the majority wishes of a population, you will then get an arrogant and ultimately corrupt government'. The situation is that in Queensland something is clearly very much amiss in the way that State is being administered.

Finally, I think that this Committee, as a permanent committee, will, over a period, be able to establish a body of opinion, of expertise, that will be used not only at the parliamentary level but also in the community and possibly in academic institutions. There is an ongoing need for the community to be aware that democracy is never 100 per cent perfect or static. There will always be debate about how it should operate. The Electoral Matters Committee will enhance that debate. I am surprised that it has taken us 87 years since Federation to establish such a committee. I believe that the Parliament and the Australian people will be well served by its establishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the former Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform I support this motion. On three matters I wrote a dissenting report in respect of recommendations that were made by the former Committee. One of those matters of dissent was the list system of voting in the Senate. The first test of a fair electoral system is whether it truly reflects the intention of the voter. When I asked the Australian Electoral Commission whether it had done a survey to ascertain whether the list system of voting truly reflected the intention of the voter, the Commission indicated that it was too late for it to conduct such a survey, some months having elapsed between the time of the election and the time that I raised the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Two days after the recent election I raised the same question with the Electoral Commissioner: How many people who went into the voting booth and voted No. 1 in the party ticket box knew precisely where their preferences were going?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that the Australian electorate is not very smart?

—I am saying that the parties have been very smart in bringing forward this electoral system. I do not know whether Senator Sanders's party still supports this method of voting, but it is particularly clear to me, at all events, from my survey of electors, that many of them did not know where there preferences were going when they chose to put a No. 1 in the box on the top of the ballot paper. This is a matter which we should not be at cross-purposes about. We ought to be doing a survey to find out whether people knew where their preferences were going and what the ultimate result was of putting a No. 1 in the box at the top of the ballot paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely this is a legitimate question. I am not fussed about it. In my State I received more votes than any other Senate candidate below the line. Having raised the question with the Australian Electoral Commissioner two days or there- abouts after the recent election, I will be interested to know what has been done by the Electoral Commission to ascertain whether the first test of a fair electoral system has been met by the list system of voting.

The motion passed by the House of Representatives effectively excluded me from membership of the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform. One has to get up early around this place. I noticed what had happened. To the Government's credit, when I raised the matter with it, it understood the argument I put forward that a fair consideration of electoral systems should be non-partisan. I acknowledge the fact that the Government is now amending the message from the House of Representatives to increase the size of the Committee by two to enable me to be a member of the Committee, as I was before, and for the Government to have an extra member on the Committee to balance it. I acknowledge my appreciation of the Government's action.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate is to abolish the two-airline agreement, an agreement which in some form or other has been around since 1952 and covers the operations of the two major airlines in Australia. The practical consequence of this motion, which is long overdue, is formally to give notice that the legislation covering the operation of the two major airlines in Australia will be disbanded. It also means inevitably that Australian Airlines-or Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) or whatever one wants to call it-will be sold. It does not matter how much the Australian Labor Party, and particularly the far Left of it, dissemble on that point; the simple facts of life are that Australian Airlines has to be sold as a consequence of this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many ironies in this. Those of us who have been here for some years will remember the debates that went on in the past about the sanctity of Australian Airlines as a government airline. That, of course, is partly understandable from the Labor Party because Australian Airlines was a creature of the Labor Government in the post-war era. The very Acts that have been on the statute book to protect the place of the two airlines in Australia were introduced to protect the airline owned by the public, namely, Australian National Airways (ANA) and, later, Ansett Airlines of Australia, from the great powers of a Commonwealth-owned airline. The very fact that they were set up to protect Ansett or its forebears against the powers of TAA has resulted, over the passage of years, in a gross erosion of the strength of TAA, to the point where today it is a very weak airline. One of the great problems which the Government has to address is how it is to keep competition in the Australian airline industry when it pulls off this legislation. But that is a problem for another day.

The origins of the two-airline agreement go back to 1952. After the Second World War, the largest airline in Australia was Australian National Airways, but it must be remembered that, up to the start of the Second World War, the airline structure in Australia was a collection of very small and very weak airlines. The hostilities of the Second World War created a great demand for air services. Because of the work which the airlines did for the defence forces, both ANA, as it was then, and Ansett grew enormously, as did some of the other large airlines at the time, such as Guinea Airways. Guinea Airways was once the largest freight carrier in the world, with its operations in New Guinea, up to the time of the Japanese invasion when it immediately lost a large part of its custom. In the post-war era, Australian National Airways was the dominant force and the Labor Party started TAA. In its early days, TAA was a great asset for the Australian public. It was very well managed and it had a lot of enthusiastic and very capable staff. It did a great thing in injecting competition into the airline industry, so much so that legislation was required to make sure that it did not dominate and create a monopoly in the transport world.

The argument that was used against TAA in those days still applies today; that is, that, being government-owned, it did not have to pay a dividend; it had no hungry shareholders screaming for a return on their capital. The argument went that it could resort-it never did-to unfair commercial practices, run at a loss, thereby driving its competition out of the market-place, and end up with a monopoly. Such a situation has never arisen. But, as a defence against that, the various two-airline Acts have been in place. When the legislation was first introduced it was a reasonable move. But those times have passed. Some of us on this side of the chamber argued very strongly against the last such piece of legislation, the abolition of which we have been given notice of, when it passed through the Senate in 1981. Some of us were unhappy about that legislation. I believed then that it did not provide any commercial competition between TAA, as it was then, and Ansett. I prophesied then that we would face increasing fares.

The present legislation guarantees the financial survival of the less able of the two airlines. That means that the more able one gets enormous profits but, most importantly, that the poor old travelling public are the people who suffer. Air fares in Australia are very high. The air service that is available to us is first class with respect to safety. The aircraft are clean and comfortable inside, but they do not fly at the times a large number of Australians want to travel. An even larger number of Australians simply cannot afford to travel. In a big country such as this there is a need to have a range of air services operating so that people can travel from Perth to Cairns, for business or commercial reasons, without having to go to the bank to borrow a few thousand dollars.

That leads me to the failures of the present legislation. The present legislation has failed because it does not provide any commercial competition. One of the other consequences of the legislation, which is not generally perceived in the public place, is a virtual domination of the air transport world in Australia by the Ansett Transport Industries (ATI) group. Very few small airlines are still in existence in Australia and very few commuter operators do not have some involvement with Ansett. This has some pretty profound consequences. I will be very interested to see what legislative practices the Government follows to control Ansett's operation in what will be very close to a monopoly situation after the legislation is abolished.

This taking over of small airlines has been going on for a long while. Queensland Airlines was taken over by Butler Air Transport, which in turn was taken over by Ansett. Ansett itself took over the old ANA after Ivan Holyman died of a heart attack in Honolulu. MacRobertson Miller Airline Services, a big carrier in Western Australia, was taken over by Ansett. Substantial interests in a lot of the commuter operators, such as Lloyd Aviation, Aeropelican and Kendall Airlines-probably the three biggest in the country at that level of operation-are held by Ansett. So Ansett dominates that part of the industry. In addition, through its associate, Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, it has a very big interest in surface transport and, of course, its hotels and resorts involvement is quite massive. The whole of the travel industry in this country is very much dominated by Ansett. My objection to that is the fundamental one that where there are monopolies there is no competition and, at the end of the day, the consumer suffers. I am not suggesting for a moment that there are not 100 different competitors in the hotel and resort business. Obviously, a huge number are competing with resorts such as Hayman Island, which operates at the top end of the scale, and so on.

We must look at the situation in terms of passenger traffic. According to the latest figures I have been able to get, Ansett has 49.8 per cent of the Australian airline traffic, Australian Airlines has 42.5 per cent and 7.7 per cent of the traffic is carried by East-West Airlines Ltd, which has been bought by Ansett within the last month. So something like 57.5 per cent of the Australian airline traffic is now carried by Ansett, leaving only 42 per cent. That is getting close to a 2:1 ratio. Unless steps are taken we will end up with a dominant ATI operation on air travel and a very weak opposing airline-Australian Airlines, or whatever it is called after it is sold off.

In my judgment, Ansett is one of the best airlines in the world today. If one forgets about the cost of its fares, it is an exceptionally good airline. I believe that it ranks with some of the best in the world. It has new, adequate and appropriate equipment. It is well managed relative to Australian Airlines, although, in airline terms, on an absolute scale, it is not well managed insofar as it costs so much to run. It is well capitalised and it has good links with the international capital markets, so it can fund its operation. It has good staff and good morale. In contrast with that operation is the Australian Airlines operation, which is largely characterised by being very run down. It has old equipment. Some of that equipment is appropriate for its tasks and some of it is not.

Australian Airlines is starting a re-equipment program. Once upon a time the thing that built TAA, as it then was, to its position of greatness in the Australian airline scene was its ability to select the right equipment at the right time. I cite as examples the purchase of the Convair 240s, the first pressurised aircraft in Australia, and the purchase of the Viscounts, the first turbo-prop aircraft. The flair that TAA showed for picking the right things at the right time, which built the airline up, has sadly now been lost. There is no argument that the failure to upgrade the DC9 and 727 fleet at the right time was one of the things that caused TAA's passenger traffic to fall off. The purchase of the Airbuses was not an inspired move at all in a financial sense. It bought two more than it should have bought. I do not know what has happened to those two aircraft; they were on long term lease at one stage. Also, the decision of this week to defer the nine A320 Airbuses should never have had to be taken. The original decision to place the order was made at entirely the wrong time for that sort of equipment.

In a general sense, the management of Australian Airlines is poor. It is woefully undercapitalised, which is not the fault of the management, but the undercapitalisation poses big problems for this Government when it comes to selling it. Australian Airlines has good staff but it is fair to say that its morale is bad and it has been for years. The Government cannot throw out the two-airline agreement, as it proposes to do, without doing something about Australian Airlines. As I said earlier, at the end of the day the position is that we have a government airline which can run at a loss and an airline owned as a public company which cannot afford to run at a loss. The only way the playing fields can be evened up and all balanced out is to sell Australian Airlines. I do not care how much the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) weaves around the point, dissembles and says that the Government will look at the problem; that is the fact of the matter. The Minister is intelligent enough to know that it is inevitable that Australian Airlines will go into public ownership at some time after this agreement is abolished.

The Minister's statement finds no criticism from this side of the House insofar as it goes. The Minister is just picking up the policy that we had in place when the present Government came into power. We had started down the path of transferring TAA to public ownership, hopefully through a system which would have allowed the employees to purchase a significant part of it. We had arranged to restructure TAA from a statutory authority to a public company. That plan was abandoned by the Australian Labor Party when it came into power and now it will have to reverse its decision.

My criticism of this statement is that it exemplifies the tunnel vision of the Minister. He sees all the problems and flaws in the Australian airline system as stemming from the fact that we have a two-airline agreement-and such is not the case. The two-airline agreement does cause us a lot of problems; that is true. But the problems of the Australian airline industry are very much wider than those coming from the two-airline agreement and there is no sign that anyone in this Government or in the Department recognises that they are much more widely based. These problems simply will not be solved, as the Minister says they will, by deregulation alone.

As someone who has been involved in aviation for a large part of his life, I am the first to get up on a soap box and complain about the overregulation of Australian aviation. I do not know any field of activity in any country which is as overregulated as the Australian aviation scene. There is a huge cost for the nation in the system we have. But I am also not in favour of the catch-as-catch-can total deregulation proposals based on the American system that are floating around. As one who goes to America regularly, I would argue that in many ways the deregulation of the American airways has led in some senses to a diminution of the service available to the public. It is true that it provides competition and it is true that the public gets a break on air travel, which never ever happens in Australia. The discount and stand-by fares we have here, while welcome, are really meaningless in the sum total of things, whereas air travellers in the United States do get some genuinely good breaks. One is able to fly between Washington and Los Angeles for about $100 return. That is the equivalent of flying the Sydney-Perth route for $100 return. These discounts are available on special occasions. Certainly one cannot walk in and buy a ticket on that basis at any time, but if one watches the papers that opportunity presents itself. My argument is that the Australian public never gets the opportunity of significantly cheap fares, and that is very much a consequence of the two-airline system.

There is not time today to go through the defects of total deregulation. I merely put on the record the fact that I certainly do not favour total deregulation. The circumstances in Australia really are quite different from those in the United States. We simply do not have the population to support such a system. But I want to come to the reason I see the Minister's statement about total deregulation as being very naive and simplistic. The Minister said that he will retain legislation only with respect to airline safety. Airline safety is absolutely paramount. But, with the best will in the world, safety cannot be legislated for. We can have safety requirements, but running a safe airline system does require regulation other than specific legislation dealing with the maintenance of aircraft and the flying of them. It has wider implications. Inevitably it involves the Government in regulating to some degree air fares and route structures. The Government cannot avoid that point; yet there is no recognition of it in what the Minister said.

We certainly do not need an independent air fares tribunal. I agree with that being abolished. But in some way we have to monitor what is going on. Otherwise we get airlines losing money and, whilst it is not the business of the Government to stop airlines or anyone else in private industry from going broke, a responsibility for governments with respect to airlines arises from the fact that an insolvent airline is always unsafe. A profitable airline is a safe airline, but an unprofitable airline cannot be a safe airline-and the link between profitability and safety is a nexus that cannot be broken. So, while we can legislate as much as we like for specific safety procedures-such as the changing of engines at certain times, fuel quality and pilot training and procedures-inevitably the wider issues of safety involve an oversight in some way by the government of what is being done with respect to route structures and fare structures. I do not know the answers to those problems. All I say is that I recognise that it is a problem of very great difficulty. Although I cannot provide the answers, I am telling the Senate that it is quite impossible for Senator Gareth Evans or any other Minister in this place to wipe his hands of safety issues once legislation which relates specifically and in a restricted sense to air safety alone has been passed. It just does not work that way.

Let me get on to some of the other problems of the Australian airline industry that are not affected by the two-airline agreement. The principal one, of course, is the maintenance of the curfews at so many airports in Australian capital cities under which between the hours of 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. no major airliner is able to operate there. The time between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. is seven hours-out of a total of 24 hours in a day. The airlines have very expensive equipment which has to be amortised and used to the hilt before it becomes obsolescent. Because of the great costs involved in air travel, advances are always being made in the mechanical efficiency of aircraft. The amount of fuel burnt by an aircraft on the major trunk routes is considerably less now than it was 15 years ago, by any measure. Modern aircraft are much more productive and much more efficient. But airlines dealing with airliners that cost anywhere between $50m and $80m and which have a service life of only 10 or 12 years cannot afford to allow their equipment to be locked up, unable to be used, for seven hours out of every 24. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Ryan is absent from the chamber for Question Time today as she is attending a conference in Melbourne. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Ryan in relation to her portfolio or those she represents in this chamber should be directed to Senator Tate.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I again refer the Minister to strong criticism by Mr Justice Ludeke of the building industry $20 a week severance pay agreements, criticism to which I referred in a question directed to the Minister on 23 September. The Minister undertook to obtain a further reply which has not yet been received. I refer also to the Minister's admission in an answer on Wednesday to Senator Parer that the Government was concerned about the failure of these agreements to satisfy either its wages policy or the wage fixing principles of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Is the Minister aware that these agreements came into force a week ago; in other words, we are not talking about some prospect off into the future? Is he further aware that the Western Australian Minister for Labour, Productivity and Employment, Mr Dowding, has warned building employers in that State that introduction of the scheme without Arbitration Commission ratification would breach the State's code of conduct for the building industry and render employers ineligible for government contracts? Are signatories to these already operative agreements also in breach of the Federal Government's code of conduct for the building and construction industry? What action will the Government take, other than polite letters after the horse has bolted, to enforce its code and to ensure that this matter is brought speedily before the Commission?

—As I indicated in answer to a question-I think it was to Senator Parer a day or two ago-the Minister wrote to the proposed parties to the various agreements in the building industry and informed them that they did not meet with the approval of the Government and sought renegotiation of those agreements. I understand that that is still the position. If there is any further information that I can provide Senator Chaney with in relation to that matter I will seek to obtain it today and do so. By the way, I was not aware of Mr Dowding's intervention.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to statistics from the Federal Attorney-General's Department which show the number of bankruptcies in Queensland has risen by nearly 100 per cent in the past three years? What has been the comparative rate of bankruptcies between the Australian States in the financial years 1983-84 to 1986-87? According to the latest information, what is the bankruptcy situation in Queensland in regard to the first half of 1987 compared with the same period last year?

—I regret to say that there is a bankruptcy in my briefing as far as this question is concerned. I am unable to answer. I will have to take it on notice and get the honourable senator a better answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the announcement of the Treasurer last week concerning changes to the regulations governing acquisition of urban residential property by foreign investors. Is the Minister aware of difficulties being experienced by both real estate agents and legal practitioners dealing with foreign purchases of real estate in obtaining clarification as to the precise details of the changes to the foreign investment regulations and that, for example, in Canberra Treasury is already advising of a two to three week delay in considering applications for approval of purchases by foreigners? Does the Minister realise that these difficulties and delays arise from the fact that the Government is attempting to legislate by Press release and enforce the new provisions before the legislation amending the Foreign Takeovers Act has even been introduced into the Parliament? When will the legislation be available?

—I was asked whether I am aware of certain complaints. The answer to that is no, I am not. I am not sure whether this question is prompted by an article in today's Australian Financial Review, a summary of which has just been handed to me and some of which is relevant to the question asked. It was suggested in the article-quite wrongly-that prior consultation with companies is practicable when policy changes of this nature are undertaken. That is a suggestion that the Government rejects. I am also advised that any company gravely affected by changes to government regulations has the option of making representations to the Government. A number of representations have been received and they are being handled quickly. As to the other parts of the question, I do not know the answers. I will refer them to the Treasurer and supply an answer as soon as I can.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Home Affairs. Can the Minister advise the Senate on progress with the preparation of the two-party preferred votes for all divisions in the House of Representatives? When will the election summaries for the House of Representatives and the Senate, known as the greens and the reds, be available for circulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Gietzelt's question, I have been a little delayed by industrial problems in the Australian Electoral Commission. Therefore, I cannot give the precise date when the preferred vote figures will be available, but it will be some time within the next four weeks. The cost is minimal. The Commission really provides information almost for political professionals or academics. Most of the work is done by existing Electoral Commission staff, though on occasions some casual staff are employed to complete that process. I imagine that some time in the next month those election results will be through. I hasten to inform Senator Gietzelt that there will be no late swings; none of the results will alter.

ANSWER.PARA: I am considering having talks with the Commission to see whether, after this occasion, the results can be presented in a different form so that we get preferred vote figures for each booth rather than for divisions as a whole. Having been a scrutineer on the odd occasion, I do not imagine that presenting them in this form will add much to the cost of the operation. I am sure that all House of Representatives members, and probably most senators, would prefer to get the figures in a booth by booth form. In recent years there has been some resistance to that by divisional returning officers. I am sure that after discussions with them we can overcome that resistance and that the figures can be produced in that form following the 1990-91 election.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Given that there has been tax reform which has significantly reduced marginal tax rates for higher income earners, given that a review of corporate taxation aimed at reducing corporate tax rates is under way, and given that 10 per cent of Australians own 60 per cent of the private wealth in this country while at least two million people still live below the poverty line, I ask: Has the Minister noted the call by the Uniting Church in Australia for an inquiry into wealth and does the Minister agree that the need for such an inquiry is now greater than ever? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether he is taking any action to initiate such an inquiry as a prelude to raising real incomes and opportunities for the poorest of Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the Labor Government has an un- equalled record both in taxation reform and in help for disadvantaged persons in the community. The introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax did much to stop the haemorrhaging of tax revenue and the mounting inequities for pay as you earn taxpayers, both of those problems having grown at such a rapid rate under the previous Fraser-Howard Administration.
—Rubbish.

—Even Mr Costigan said it was the only industry that grew under the Liberals. I think he used the expression that it was reminiscent of the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. The reduction in marginal tax rates was thus part of an improvement in the equity and progressivity of personal income tax provisions. Those measures are now, by and large, accepted right across our community, including through most of the business community. Our continuing efforts to assist pensioners and social security beneficiaries and working families also provide, I must say, a sharp contrast with the efforts of previous administrations, in particular that run by John Howard. Comparisons of the election programs of the Government and the Opposition bear the real testimony to that. There is no question, certainly in the minds of all those who are underprivileged in this society, that the Liberals would turn back the clock.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is already taking action to raise the real income levels of low income families and from the Budget up to one million children from 500,000 families can benefit by up to $28 per week per child. With respect to the latter part of Senator Powell's question, on the call by the Uniting Church for an inquiry into wealth, I would say, first, that the Government is appreciative of all that the Uniting Church has done in recent years to bring forward the plight of underprivileged in our community. I have had many dealings with it on that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not only a born again greenie; you are a born again Christian.

—I have never described myself as a born again greenie; that is what others have said. There is of course no need for me to be born again as a Christian. I understand that a group of officers from the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been meeting for some time to conduct an examination of the available databases on wealth. For all of the reasons that I have outlined over the last couple of minutes I have not taken any action myself and at the moment there is no proposal before the Government for a wealth inquiry.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to an article in the Canberra Times of 2 October entitled `$1.5m cut in Federal Police budget'. How does the Minister reconcile that article with his statement on Budget night that the Australian Federal Police's budget had been increased?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question, which draws my attention to an article in the Canberra Times of Friday, 2 October headed `$1.5m cut in Federal Police budget'. I must say that I was quite astonished when I read that headline because the article claimed to find some support for that headline in comments made from my office, a claim which I know to be utterly unfounded. The fact is that, whilst at some early stages of the Budget process some savings were required of the Australian Federal Police-along with all other elements of the portfolio and indeed all other elements of government administration-which amounted to, I think, $1.26m, at the end of the day and as a consequence of this Federal Government's very strong supportive role in relation to the Federal Police, which it regards as its pre-eminent law enforcement agency, the Australian Federal Police ended up with an increase in its funding of some $10m. Indeed, if I may give the exact figure, a total of $150.669m was provided, compared with expenditure last year of $141.305m.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the provision of more financial resources which can pay for operational matters and which in particular were directed to enhancing the computer capacity of the Australian Federal Police, there was an addition of some 104 in average staffing level, which I think all honourable senators would agree represented, in the present budgetary climate, a very significant advance for the Australian Federal Police. It represented, as to 94 of those persons, the third year of a program which was initiated by the Prime Minister in 1984 and which has led to an increase in resources and staff for the Australian Federal Police, plus an additional 10 or so staff to deal with other matters arising out of the anti-organised crime package which was passed by this Parliament in the latter week of the autumn session earlier this year. So altogether, the Australian Federal Police, as I think was made manifest during the Estimates Committee hearings yesterday, was well placed as a result of this Government's support, both in terms of resources and of staff, to continue the battle against organised crime. As I have said, it is recognised as, is acting as, and is securing success as the Government's premier law enforcement agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to his Government's failure to fulfil its previously stated commitment to ensuring that all remote telephone connections be converted to an automatic system by 1990. Is the Minister aware of the widespread frustration and anger felt by 18,000 people still waiting to be connected under the rural and remote area program, especially as many of these people agreed to what they thought would be a temporary downgrading in their services while waiting to be connected to the automatic system? Does the Minister agree that the situation is discriminatory and that people who live in these areas are entitled to a telephone service which is the equivalent of that received by other Australians? Can he give an undertaking to investigate this matter and ensure that the Telecom Australia rural and remote area program is completed by 1990? If not, will the Minister accompany me to remote Queensland so that he can experience personally the hardships and frustrations of living and trying to run a business without a telephone, at its worst, or with an inferior party line, at its best?

—I have had some irresistible invitations in my time and I have had some resistible ones. I have to say that Senator Boswell's latter suggestion falls into the latter category. I was not aware about the frustration and anger of the 18,000 citizens to whom he referred, but I have been suitably touched by his plea on their behalf today. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Are the economic policies of the Queensland Government holding back Australia's overall economic performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.
