TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the Government's decision to introduce a tendering system for the issue of new broadcasting licences which is forecast to raise $22m in the current financial year. In the light of the absence of legislation to date to implement the Government's proposal and the fact that legislation is unlikely to be introduced into the Parliament before the end of October, which will mean that it is highly doubtful that the Government would be able to apply the proposed new arrangements to those service areas where it expects to raise all the revenue this year, especially for the Gold Coast, can the Minister explain how the $22m which is estimated in the Budget will be raised? Further, does the Minister agree that, if legislation is not in place within two to three weeks, it would create severe administrative problems both for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) and for the various applicants for the Gold Coast, Geelong, Shepparton and Gosford licences if they were subsequently required to operate under the proposed new arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept any of the premises on which that question is based. It is intended to introduce the legislation in the next sitting period and, unless it is met with obstruction from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in this place joining together, that legislation should, of course, go through in a reasonable period and enable arrangements to be put in place for the licences to be issued, one would have thought, early in 1988. No particular complexity is envisaged about the processes that will operate under the new legislative regime that was announced in outline on Budget night. Obviously there is more detail that can be and will be filled in at the time of the introduction of the legislation itself.

ANSWER.PARA: But, basically, it is a two-tier process, the first tier of which will involve the Tribunal assessing the suitability of the licensees by reference to criteria which will be very similar, if not precisely identical, to the criteria already in the legislation and around which the licensees have already built their applications. There will not be a necessity to substantially amend or modify the applications to meet the initial suitability assessment criteria. The second tier of the system will involve simply the opening of envelopes-the sealed bids of those licence applicants who are assessed to be suitable as at stage one. That is not a time-consuming process. All in all, there is absolutely no reason to make the series of assumptions that Senator Messner seems to have made in drawing his very negative conclusions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. But is he aware that the first licence-that of the Gold Coast-will not be finalised until at least before the middle to end of February 1988, and that will then be followed by the three other licences which will obviously be finalised some time well into 1988? How then can he justify his claim that he will be able to get $22m this financial year? On the point of viability, is it not a fact that the ABT will need to know how much is being tendered before it can establish the financial viability of the applicants?

—I know that Senator Messner is a frustrated administrator and he is just busting to get his teeth back into a ministry so that he can wreak the kind of havoc that he and his predecessors have in the past, but I just assure him that if he leaves the matter in the competent hands in which it presently is, within the present administration of the Broadcasting Tribunal and the Department of Transport and Communications, it will be perfectly possible to perform in accordance with the timetable that we have obviously relied upon in making our budgetary assessments.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether it is true that Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara flew into Australia yesterday under an assumed name and was met by officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at Tullamarine Airport in Melbourne. Is it not true that Ratu Mara had a half hour telephone conversation with the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister while he was in Australia? Since the Government must have been aware of Ratu Mara's intended visit in advance, was this information conveyed to Dr Bavadra's envoy during his meeting with the Foreign Minister on Wednesday afternoon? Since Ratu Mara is a private citizen of Fiji and does not represent any legally elected government or body, is preferential treatment being given to him in that the Australian Government refused to meet with Dr Bavadra, the legal Prime Minister of Fiji, earlier this year? The Prime Minister will be aware that Ratu Mara has accepted the demands made by Colonel Rabuka for a racist constitution, a constitution rightly condemned by the Prime Minister. Why then are the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister holding talks with Ratu Mara? What status does the Australian Government accord Ratu Mara, and will it be supporting his credentialling at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver?

—Senator Wood was kind enough to give me notice of this question at 1 o'clock today, and I am seeking an answer. I hope to be able to provide it by the end of Question Time. I do not accept all the assumptions underlying the question. It is very much directed to a question of fact, and I will seek to obtain an answer.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that the Trade Practices Commission and the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation both concluded that barriers to entry are of such magnitude that the airline industry is not fully contestable and that, of existing regional airlines, only East-West Airlines Ltd had sufficient financial resources to contest the trunk route network? In view of the takeover of East-West by Ansett Airlines of Australia, does the Minister agree that the Government's deregulation proposals are likely to result in a decrease in competition, with adverse effects upon Australian consumers?

—No, the Government does not agree that there is any likelihood of a decrease in competition as a result of deregulation. What will happen as a result of the East-West takeover by Ansett depends very much on the outcome of proceedings and procedures presently in train before the Trade Practices Commission, and no assumptions should be made at this stage as to the outcome of those proceedings. I have indicated on a number of occasions in the last few days that there are obvious difficulties in contemplating the arrival on the Australian aviation scene of a major new third force, a fully equipped fleet owner operating 30-odd aircraft, which is presently the case with both Ansett and Australian Airlines. There is no doubt about that unless, as I have said on one or two occasions, there is a billionaire around with a smell of kerosene in his nostrils and a disposition to tear up $100 bills at a rapid rate. It may be difficult to find an entrant into the Australian market on that scale. But there are plenty of market opportunities, simply because of the scale of the Australian aviation industry.
—East-West would have been a handy competitor, would it not?

—I ask the honourable senator to hold his expectations about East-West. As I have said, a lot depends on the outcome of the proceedings-and there are a few other things he ought to be holding too-before the Trade Practices Commission.
—Holding what?

—His breath, I mean. A lot can be said and speculated upon so far as the competitive environment post-deregulation is concerned. I think a reasonable expectation at this stage is that the competition, apart from that provided by each of the present players against the other-and that is something we are obviously keen to shore up; that is what the whole strategy about Australian Airlines is about-is likely to arise from niche entrants, people taking advantage of particular market opportunities, whether in the regional, commuter or feeder airline areas, or perhaps even on major trunk routes, involving the importation of a handful of wide-bodied aircraft on the model of the United States People's Express or something of that kind. There are many ways in which scenarios of this kind can unfold post-1990. I am not sure how productive it is to speculate about them. But to suggest that this body of policy that we have now announced and will put in place will somehow amount to an environment which is less competitive than that which prevails at the moment, is to quite profoundly misread the situation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government examined proposals reported in today's Sydney Morning Herald that marginal rates of income tax could be lowered to the point where the incentive to provide fringe benefits is reduced and the fringe benefits tax could be abolished? Is the proposal within the bounds of fiscal responsibility? If so, will the Government implement it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of the question, I do not think one could say with any certainty whether the proposal is within the bounds of fiscal responsibility until more details are available as to what is being proposed. What we can be quite certain of, of course, is that the policies put forward by both Opposition parties before the last election were way beyond the bounds of fiscal responsibility. On one side of the ledger there were promises of enormous tax cuts which were not matched with specified expenditure cuts. That applies equally to Senator Stone's policy-as it really was, of course, although it was presented by the present Queensland Premier-and to the Liberal Party policy, except that in Senator Stone's contribution the internal arithmetic was consistent, unlike that of the official Opposition policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. As I said, it does not give any details of the level of a proposed consumption tax or of the proposed new income tax rates scale. Without those details one cannot really be sure whether it is responsible. It appears that the story came out some time after the 6 p.m. announcement by the Premier of Queensland yesterday that he was going to retire in 10 months time. It now seems that he will retire very much earlier than that-about next Wednesday. I noticed that Senator Stone welcomed the announced retirement. Indeed, to use his own words, according to today's Australian, the retirement announcement by the Premier was `very much to be welcomed'. I think that Senator Stone would equally welcome the earlier and involuntary retirement of the Premier which now seems likely to occur next Wednesday, which would be even more welcome than his planned voluntary retirement 10 months hence.

There are other quite irresponsible, false assertions in the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald, the most spectacular of which is that there would be no need for fringe benefits taxes if the marginal tax rate was lower. One would have to be very naive to believe that, once people have devised some trick, some way of defining their income out of existence, and have got away with it-as they got away with it for the best part of a decade, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, during most of which period, of course, Mr Howard was Treasurer-because the marginal tax rate had come down from 49c to 40c, 30c or even 20c, they will suddenly stop defining their income out of existence and pay whatever rate of tax they are obliged to pay, or ought to pay. For that suggestion to work, the marginal tax rate would have to come down to zero or very close to it. Even in Senator Stone's pre-election proposition, the marginal tax rate was 25c in the dollar. He only specified about $4.5 billion of the necessary offsetting expenditure cuts. By 1991 $22.5 billion would be required. In short--

TALK.START.PARA: —In short? Six minutes so far!

—Should I say, in summary-there is one thing in the report which, if correct, I would welcome, and I believe every member of this Government would welcome it. That is that one Liberal is quoted as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We believe there are going to have to be top-to-bottom changes to the tax policy, otherwise we'll face the same question at the next election: where's the money coming from?

If that is indicative of a shift towards fiscal responsibility by the Liberal Party-in marked contrast to its behaviour up until now-that will be a change, if it really happens, which I think everybody should welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is it a fact that the union featherbedding practices which have been a major ingredient in the massive overrun of costs of the new Parliament House have now flowed on to other building sites in the Australian Capital Territory? Is he aware that the new Hyatt hotel is one construction site which is suffering from these practices and that the Hyatt company, which has been reluctant to pay the costs of these practices, has been told its project will not be completed on time as a result? Further, is the Minister aware that the Hyatt organisation has interviewed, selected and promised jobs in the new Hyatt to 300 potential employees but is unable to engage or train them because it does not know when the new hotel will open? Finally, is the Minister aware that the Hyatt has flown four of its top employee relations officers to Canberra to counsel these potential employees, most of whom are local residents? Will the Minister take steps to eliminate from that site the practices which were born and nurtured in the new Parliament House building, and, by so doing, set an example for other construction sites in the Australian Capital Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, Senator Bishop's question is based on false assumptions. It is unfortunate that she probably has not read the statement by the Minister for Administrative Services which we tabled in this House today and much other material relating to this area. I would be the last person to stand here and say that every work practice in the building industry is justified. It is quite clear from the comments of Government Ministers on a number of occasions that they have urged an improvement of work practices-be they in terms of a productivity trade-off or other things in the building industry. One thing I can say with a degree of certainty is that many of the work practices to which the honourable senator referred were not nurtured, as she said, on the new Parliament House site. Whilst there may be some unsavoury work practices on the new Parliament House site, the general evidence is that they are no worse than anywhere else and, in many cases, nowhere near as bad. The new Parliament House construction site has not been a pacesetter in this regard. Problems that have occurred on that site have reflected problems generally in the building industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bishop went on to make some comments about the development of the Hyatt hotel. I do not know the exact details relating to those parts of the question she raised. However, in my general experience, the sooner Canberra gets a Hyatt hotel the better so that we can at least have one first class hotel in this city. I will go no further than that but I do not think many senators in this chamber would disagree with me. I will talk to the portfolio Minister, Mr West, in regard to the questions relating to the Hyatt hotel and will try to get the honourable senator a prompt response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Environment and the Arts whether he can clarify reports that the Federal Government is appeasing some conservation groups by, for example, greatly increasing their funding and by nominating the wet tropical rainforests for world heritage listing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some of the reports referred to by Senator Black in his question. I think that some of them emanate from a speech by Mr Downer in the other place. I think probably they bear some witness to why he is no longer the shadow Minister for Environment and the Arts. He still seems to be plagued by the same difficulties he had when he was shadow Minister. How he could get so much wrong is a bit of a mystery. However, I will attempt to correct some of his claims. He claimed that funding to the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) and the Wilderness Society had increased by 20 per cent in nominal terms and by about 13 per cent in real terms. I am sure that those groups wish that those claims were true but they are not. Grants to individual conservation groups have not yet been determined.

ANSWER.PARA: He broadened that statement by saying that grants to voluntary organisations are to be increased by 20 per cent this year as part of some prearranged election pay-off. The general figure for total outlays for grants to voluntary conservation groups has been determined. The increase was 1.17 per cent, hardly a great pay-off to conservation groups. I just have to say that he got it wrong again. He claimed that for the first time the Budget Papers did not give a breakdown of how that sum would be distributed to conservation groups. He said that the ACF and the Wilderness Society will get increased funding of 20 per cent. As I have said, the breakdown just has not been determined.

He got not only the administrative side of his former portfolio wrong but also the technical facts wrong. He claimed that 75 per cent of Queensland rainforests are already within the national parks. Don't we wish that that were true? Of course it is not. One of the reasons why the Government acted to protect the rainforests of north Queensland was that only 16 per cent of them were within national parks. Unfortunately, Mr Downer was not able to distinguish between timber reserves and State forests. A considerable number of rainforests are within timber reserves but not within national parks. Were they within national parks the Government could have considered its position although, given the record of the Queensland Government on national parks, I am not so sure. We all recall Lindeman Island where there was a national park which some years ago the Government wanted to ditch for some developers.

All I can say is that we will not allow all of those areas, including timber reserves, to remain in State forests that are so vulnerable to logging. The truth is that up to the election the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia on the question of world heritage listing was that it would agree to it provided the Queensland Government also agreed. Like Mr Downer, we all await breathlessly to hear what decision the coalition will make, whether Senator Stone or Senator Puplick will prevail. I am not sure whether the views of the Premier of Queensland are all that relevant any longer. I will take some steps to contact Mr Ahern and see whether there might be a change to the situation in Queensland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to a Press release of 6 June 1986 from the former Special Minister of State, Mr Young, announcing the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth, which reported recently. In that Press statement Mr Young stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Fraud prevention by departments is hampered by lack of accurate information.
Figures ranging from $4 billion a year to as high as $30 billion have been cited.
These figures could be exaggerated. The simple fact is we just don't know.

Is it a fact that, despite the completion of the review, we still do not know the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth? Does the Minister believe that effective action against fraud can be instituted without any assessment of the extent of the problem? Did the review make an attempt to determine the level of fraud, as Mr Young had implied it would? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recently tabled report of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth is, I think, now accepted by honourable senators on both sides of the chamber as being evidence of this Government's determination to tackle fraud where it is occurring within government agencies. It represents our putting our own house in order, which I think is welcomed by all those who have taken some care to acquaint themselves with the situation. Senator Archer mentioned a date back in 1986 when the former Special Minister of State, Mr Young, made some comments about the need to overcome the somewhat wild and exaggerated differences in the claims that are made about the extent of fraud on the Commonwealth which range, as Senator Archer mentioned in his question, over many billions of dollars. The range of the various extravagant claims that are made indicates that there is a need to come more precisely to grips with the types and extent of fraud against the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why this latest review was established and has undertaken to bring about within government agencies a system of prevention, detection and investigation of fraud. We believe that it will lead to a much needed relieving of pressure on downstream agencies like the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, and resources in the court system, which are at present overwhelmed by matters which ought at best to be prevented or otherwise dealt with by detection and investigation within the Commonwealth agencies concerned. I hope that that will be the case.

The clearest example of that is the situation that obtained for many years, where the Federal Police were undertaking many thousands of staff hours of work to deal with cases where social security cheques had been sent in the mail to recipients who claimed that the cheques had been stolen or not received and so were entitled to emergency relief payment over the social security counter. The fraud involved in that method of payment was such that the Federal Police were totally overwhelmed. When the Government moved to making such payments direct to bank accounts, a tremendous load was lifted from the shoulders of the Federal Police and that has enabled them to concentrate on more important and extensive frauds against the Commonwealth. That is an example of what we hope will flow from the work of the fraud control committee. That committee is being set up as a result of this review and it will vigorously and rigorously supervise the implementation of those measures which the review recommended. The Government accepted all the important recommendations of that review, bar some review of certain secrecy provisions which are being looked at in accordance with the real misgivings and disquiet that have been aroused in the community concerning privacy issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the information that he provided, but he did not make any effort to answer the question. In view of the considerable difference in the nature and the extent of the recovery operation, depending on whether the assessed extent of the fraud be $1 billion, $5 billion or $20 billion, I ask the Minister: In what general areas does the Government assess the figure to be? How much money is it?

—The Government has made no assessment across the board of the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth in monetary terms. The White Paper presented to the National Taxation Summit dealt with an estimate of the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth in relation to the tax system, and that was estimated to be about $3 billion. That has always formed the major part of the basis of the claims about fraud against the Commonwealth, ranging from $4 billion to $5 billion to $9 billion to $11 billion, depending on the extravagance of the Press release put out by various organisations. That fraud against the tax system, which is something with which the Australian Federal Police are not particularly competent to deal, has always formed the major basis of claims about the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth.
—How much are we looking at?

—I am telling the honourable senator. Insofar as the Commonwealth has made any assessment, it has been in relation to the tax fraud against the Commonwealth and it is in the region outlined in the White Paper and presented to the Tax Summit.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask the Minister whether he has read the article in the Australian Financial Review magazine for September 1987 by Brian Toohey entitled `Sub-contracting our Navy'. If so, could he tell the Senate whether it is true that somewhere between $500m and $1 billion could have been saved on Australia's new submarine contract if the capability for espionage activities performed on behalf of the United States Navy were dropped? Could he further say whether it is true that in the past, Australia's submarines have carried out patrols off the coast of the Soviet Union in the North West Pacific, to which the article refers? If so, could we know what such activities have to do with the defence of Australia, and why should the Australian taxpayer subsidise such dangerous activities on behalf of the Unites States in this way? Finally, is it true that the United States Navy wanted Australia to build conventional submarines rather than nuclear submarines because the former are much quieter and therefore more useful for staying on silent patrol within range of Soviet bases in the northern Pacific?

—In answer to the first part of the question-whether I have read an article by Mr Brian Toohey-the answer is no. When I organise the priorities of my life I guess that I would rank that somewhere between having lunch with Wilson Tuckey and having lunch with a child murderer. Fortunately, someone in the Department of Defence has read the article. I might just say, editorialising, that it is the brand of character assassination and paranoia that Mr Toohey normally exhibits. Some claims do appear in that article. The honourable senator has isolated three points to which she would like a response. In answer to the first part of the question, the capabilities of the new submarines meet the characteristics required to satisfy Australian needs as laid down in the 1987 Defence White Paper tabled by the Minister for Defence this year. With reference to the second question, as to where the submarines go, the Minister for Defence does not comment on the operational activities of Royal Australian Navy submarines. The answer to the third part of the question is a straight no. The capabilities of the new submarine reflect Australian national requirements, and no others.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Are there any parts of the off-shore constitutional settlement package that remain outstanding? If so, what further proclamations are required? Can the Minister explain the reasons for the elements that are still outstanding?
—I will have to refer that question to the Attorney-General and obtain an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the West Australian newspaper on 2 October 1987 entitled `Special child-care centre faces axe' and a report later that day on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television program the 7.30 Report on the same subject? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal axe threatens Perth's only child-care centre taking chronically ill children.

It further alleged that Federal funding for a new building to replace the present premises at the Princess Margaret Hospital had been refused, as had a claim for an extra $100,000 in funds to cover the extended hours of operation of the centre. I ask: Are the claims made in the article and on the 7.30 Report accurate? If not, what is the situation? Finally, I ask: Have any of the reporters made any attempt to confirm the details contained in the respective news items prior to broadcasting and going to print?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to have a rather full brief on this matter. I will acquaint Senator McKiernan and the chamber with the contents of it. The Princess Margaret Hospital child care centre in Perth is one of 19 centres across Australia which have been receiving Commonwealth Government subsidies over and above what other child care centres receive. In April 1986 this temporary assistance was made available for 12 months to high cost child care centres after changes were made to child care funding arrangements. One hundred and eighty six centres were offered transitional assistance at that time. Transitional assistance was intended to help centres adjust to the new funding arrangements. All except a handful of centres managed to take the necessary steps to reduce their costs and fees to acceptable levels. This small group, which included the Princess Margaret Hospital Centre, received a second offer of transitional assistance for a further six months. That six-month period expires on 30 September.

ANSWER.PARA: The Princess Margaret child care centre and the other centres have known for 18 months that their additional subsidies were temporary. The Princess Margaret centre will continue to receive its normal child care funding of operational subsidies and fee relief. In addition, as an extended hour centre, it also now receives twice the standard operational subsidy for the extended hours component of its services. To further extend transitional assistance would be inequitable and unfair to the vast majority of other high cost centres which have taken effective steps, not always painlessly, to reduce their costs.

However, the case of the Princess Margaret centre is different from the other high cost centres in that it has also recently asked the Government for a capital grant of $728,000, more than twice the usual cost of a child care centre, to relocate. I would like to point out that when funding was originally approved for this centre it was on the firm understanding that the centre would need to be moved from its present temporary premises to new premises as part of the new hospital, funding for which is a State government responsibility. The Government believes that it has fulfilled its obligations to the Princess Margaret Child Centre. We recognise that it performs a valuable service to Perth families and that it has a specialist role caring for children with special problems. These factors have been taken into account in determining its funding. Finally, I am assured that no attempt was made by either the ABC's 7.30 Report or the West Australian newspaper to check their story with the responsible Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and relates to certain comments made by Mr Kelty about salary increases. By how much has Mr Kelty's salary increased since the Hawke Government came to office as a direct result of the Government's appointment of Mr Kelty to various boards and commissions, such as the Board of the Reserve Bank? By how much has Mr Kelty's gross salary been inflated by matters such as sitting fees, travel allowance and free overseas trips as a result of his government appointments? Is it a fact that Mr Kelty's gross salary has probably increased by in the vicinity of 30 to 50 per cent since the election of the Hawke Government?

—Senator Puplick might be surprised to find out that Mr Kelty's salary does not come within the province of my portfolio or, indeed, that of any Minister. I will endeavour to obtain an answer by arranging for somebody to ring Mr Kelty and ask him some of these questions or, alternatively, Senator Puplick could do it himself.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the deteriorating situation in Fiji, including the recent closure of trade union offices by the military, will the Government consider implementing import and export bans on Fiji and strengthening its warning to prospective Australian tourists intending to visit Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made very clear its attitude to the current events in Fiji. We have condemned Colonel Rabuka's second coup on 25 September. We have made it clear that we do not recognise the republic declared by him on 7 October or any government established by him. We continue to recognise the executive authority of the Governor-General. We have taken action to reinforce that condemnation of the coup by suspending the aid program with the exception of training costs for on-going students from Fiji. We have done it by continuing the suspension of the defence co-operation program and by noting that the nature and level of our representation in Fiji is now under review. What we have not done is to implement trade or economic sanctions and it is the Government's policy not to do so in this situation. We simply do not see economic sanctions as being practicable. There might be a short period when they would have an impact but Fiji would be able to put alternative supply arrangements in place quickly, as was demonstrated during the period of trade unions bans after the first coup. Fiji put considerable effort into diversifying sources of supply away from Australia and New Zealand with a manifest degree of success although admittedly it was not conclusive because the bans were lifted and Fiji's efforts then ceased.

ANSWER.PARA: Another consideration is that Fiji is a major transhipment point for goods and services to many of the smaller island countries in the South Pacific. They would be more likely to be affected earlier and more severely than Fiji by Australian sanctions. Prima facie it would be extremely difficult to supervise effective sanctions on exports of Australian goods, for example, to ensure that commodities shipped from Australia to other destinations were not then subsequently transhipped to Fiji. Generally speaking, sanctions are only likely to be effective when they are broadly based and have a wide measure of international support. It is our judgment that any attempt by Australia to co-ordinate an international campaign to bring about such sanctions in the context of Fiji is highly unlikely to be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to moves by the Victorian Government to ban tobacco advertising and to the counter-threat by the tobacco industry to mount a massive advertising campaign designed specifically to defeat the Victorian legislative moves. Firstly, is it true that the tobacco industry will be able to claim this overtly political advertising as a tax deduction? Secondly, is it also true that citizens who advertise a political view not linked with a commercial activity are not able to claim a tax deduction for advertising expenses? Thirdly, does the Minister think that this discrimination is fair? Fourthly, will he move to support his Victorian colleagues by removing the tax deductibility of tobacco advertising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of the question I will refer to the Treasurer. What the Victorian Government chooses to do in Victoria is the Victorian Government's affair. As to one of the earlier questions, whether the tobacco industry, if it mounted a massive advertising campaign of a political nature, would be able to claim that as a tax deduction, it probably would because of the difficulty of defining `political'. But I will get a more definitive answer from the Treasurer than that. I would think that any private citizen who ran such a campaign would not be able to claim it as a tax deduction.

ANSWER.PARA: To give an example, I think it was two days ago in here I answered a question about the Queensland Cane Growers Council which apparently provided a large amount of money to the National Farmers Federation to fund the National Farmers Federation's anti-Labor campaign in the run-up to the last Federal election. The ultimate source of those funds would be the deduction from the cane growers' deliveries to sugar mills, which would be an allowable deduction for those growers. I say that in order to point out some of the difficulties which are encountered when an attempt is made to deny tax deductibility for advertising expenses for what is, prima facie, a political campaign but which is associated with an industrial issue as well.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier at Question Time today Senator Wood asked me a question about whether Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara had visited Australia under an assumed name. It is not known whether he visited Australia under an assumed name, but he did transit Australia on his way to London as an emissary of the Fiji Governor-General, Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau, whose executive authority the Government continues to recognise-a position which I am sure is supported by the honourable senator who asked the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Ratu Mara was met by an official of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at Tullamarine Airport and shown the normal courtesies extended to visiting dignitaries. I can confirm that while in Australia Ratu Mara had a telephone conversation with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Ratu Mara transited Australia at very short notice. I am not able to inform the Senate as to whether that information was available to Mr Hayden when he met with Dr Bavadra's colleague on 7 October. As I have already mentioned, Ratu Mara was shown the normal courtesies extended to visiting dignitaries. He was not given preferential treatment. As the honourable senator knows, Dr Bavadra did not visit Australia. I am not aware that Ratu Mara is seeking to be accredited at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting at Vancouver.

The Australian Government's position on the present situation in Fiji is very clear. It has been spelt out on numerous occasions over the past couple of weeks. We continue to recognise the Governor-General's executive authority. We want to see a return to a parliamentary system in which the rights of all Fijian citizens are properly recognised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Newman asked me a question about a review of the defence service home loans scheme. I undertook to take the question on notice and I have now obtained a reply. Senator Newman sought information as to whether a determination had yet been made. The answer is no. Secondly, she asked when the results would be made public. I am advised that the Government has announced a proposal to replace the loan with a non-repayable, non-taxable cash grant of $10,000. The proposal is subject to consultation with the Returned Services League of Australia and other interested bodies. The Government intends to have the review completed by the end of 1987, when a public announcement will be made.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Newman asked a supplementary question as to whether the proposals announced in the Budget would achieve the objective. The answer to her supplementary question is that the proposed $10,000 grant would represent the lump sum equivalent of the interest concession that a borrower receives on an average defence service home loan. The proposed grant scheme would have the following advantages to the recipient: Firstly, the recipient would no longer have to take out expensive bridging finance; secondly, it would avoid, in most instances, the need to arrange a second mortgage and, therefore, save on loan establishment fees and the like; thirdly, it would reduce the deposit gap and increase the beneficiary's equity in the property; and, fourthly, as it is not tied to a particular property, the benefit would be fully portable from home to home. For the typical borrower, the grant would reduce the total amount of the repayments that would be required to be made to finance a home purchase.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's shameful and politically motivated deferral of the overwhelming case for immediate privatisation of Australian Airlines and its refusal to open the domestic airline industry to genuine competition.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring this matter of public importance before the Senate because I believe that, to date, there has been only a superficial understanding of what has really been presented to the Australian community by Senator Evans as Minister for Transport and Communications. What we have been offered is not open skies; rather, a mirage. There has been no sell-off of Australian Airlines; but there has certainly been a sell-out. If one talks in terms of open skies, the end result is that it is all sunshine for Ansett Airlines of Australia and all rain for Australian Airlines. Firstly, I want to examine the supposed committee of review that has been established by the Government for the purported purpose of considering the need to expand the capital base of Australian Airlines and to look at certain efficiency requirements that there might be.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this is a meaningless and empty charade. There are five members of the committee, one of whom is Mr Kelty. Perhaps we will be told in the near future just how much he will get for his services on this board of review. If one were to approach it in terms of the service that will be rendered by that committee, his return should be absolutely naught, because that committee is a fraud. It is to report back prior to the Australian Labor Party national conference. Quite clearly, it is designed to legitimise a decision that has already been taken to privatise, at least in part, Australian Airlines, and it consists of a number of the Government's best friends. Hopefully, it will lock in people such as Mr Kelty. Hopefully, it will have the support of that long time champion of the public sector, Dr Wilenski. No doubt it has on board Mr Harris, who is one of the golfing tutors of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), because he will be the Chairman of Australian Airlines in due course.

Just to show the degree of hypocrisy that attaches to the establishment of this committee, which will report on the blindingly obvious in due course, for political purposes, I will refer to some of the remarks that are already on the public record by people such as Mr Harris and the retiring Chairman of Australian Airlines, Mr Neil Smith. In April this year Mr Smith said that he would not object to partial sale of the Government's domestic airline to help make it more competitive. He complained about the scheme that would allow interlining rights. As one might expect, he was not terribly enthusiastic about the prospect of competition from Qantas Airways Ltd. He also opposed the relaxation of import controls.

But Mr Smith made it blindingly clear that Australian Airlines was in desperate financial trouble. In fact, he revealed that a leading Australian financial company has recently reported to Australian Airlines that it could justify, and needed, a capital base of $300m. I will deal further with this matter in a moment, but the reality is that it has a capital base of something like $130m. Applying the real earnings in the last financial year from its activities as an airline and disregarding the returns from sales of assets, the airline is probably not worth much more than that. It is clear-and it is known to everyone on the record, including blind Gareth, no doubt-that this airline is in desperate need of an immediate capital injection of the order of $170m to $200m. That is well known to Mr Neil Smith, and it is certainly well known to Mr Ted Harris. In an article of 27 August he is reported as having said that the airline must either be privatised or have all government restrictions lifted to allow it to compete. He said that it faced a tough task-that is fairly polite language, I would have thought-competing against Ansett. He said that, as far as he was concerned, it was very necessary that a lot of the constraints on Australian Airlines be removed.

What does all that mean? It means that this committee has been established to report on what is already on the public record from at least one of its members and on what must be well known to the Government. It is clearly a politically motivated decision to disguise the reality. The reality, of course, is that the Government will go down the privatisation path, despite the hypocrisy contained in a whole welter of statements that have been made over the last two years on the topic of privatisation. Let me touch on several such statements. In May 1985 in the House of Representatives, Mr Keating said:

No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics . . . The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth . . . We are not about wrecking them and selling them.

On the same day, he said that the sale of `Trans Australia Airlines . . . is simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities'. I suppose he will come along and say that of course he did not mention Australian Airlines. Mr Hawke said:
. . . the Government's position is clear. We will not sell the government-owned, publicly controlled institutions which are there to look after the rural people too.
From Mr Hawke we also heard that privatisation:
is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. They would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.
Need I go on?

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't need to go on. You can sit down.

—I would have thought that Senator Evans was long ago convinced of the necessity for such an action in whole or in part. But let me quote the breathtaking statement made today by one who aspired not so long ago to join us, that is, Mr Halfpenny. Mr Halfpenny made allegations that there was a very close relationship between Sir Peter Abeles and the Government to the extent that he regarded what has recently transpired as `Abelising' the industry. He has called for a Senate committee of inquiry to investigate that relationship, and I am only sorry that he cannot be with us here to chair the committee in due course. But, whilst I am not an avid subscriber to conspiracy theories, looking at the outcome I find it very hard to resist the temptation to question the whole series of coincidences that have resulted in Ansett Airlines being a mile in front. Of course, the ultimate beneficiaries are the Prime Minister's mega-mates.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no coincidence, I would have thought, that in the last few days we have had two very interesting announcements that can be juxtaposed against each other. The first was the announcement by Australian Airlines that unfortunately it was not able to proceed with the purchase of $650m worth of Airbuses. Poor old Mr Strong had to hawk his body around Europe, pleading to be allowed to get out of the contract. Eventually he was told that as long as he kept his deposit in place he would be allowed to buy them at some later date. So Australian Airlines cried poor, absolutely bankrupt, and could not do anything to purchase. On the other hand Ansett Airlines has told us that it is going ahead with a $1 billion purchase of Airbuses and the like. It has stitched up the business. It is going to be awash with aircraft. It will be very well placed indeed to take all other competitors to the cleaners.

So what do we find? We find that Australian Airlines will suffer that most agonising fate-death by slow strangulation. The confirmation of this is an announcement made only today by the Minister that the Trade Practices Act will, if necessary, be used to stop Ansett ruling the skies. If that is not an admission that this whole policy is designed to create a one horse race--

TALK.START.PARA: —Under another chairman, perhaps.

—Perhaps indeed. One can only hope that the next chairman will not have such a close interest in the outcome. It is a tragedy that Senator Evans confirms the disaster of this recent announcement by indicating that it will be necessary in due course to take more regulatory action. That is a tragedy, because what we should be all about is further competition in the industry. Indeed, Senator Evans is acutely aware of the David and Goliath contest that is about to emerge. Without pre-empting the outcome of the Trade Practices Commission decision in relation to East-West Airlines Ltd, it is quite unlikely, I would have thought, that we will have a result that will be more competitive. If that is the case, Senator Evans will then be put into an even greater quandary, where he will either be forced to overturn the Trade Practices Commission decision or somehow hope that greater competition will emerge in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to take a moment to highlight the disparity between the state of poverty that Australian Airlines has to endure and the state of wealth of Ansett Airlines, which, in recent months, has not only gone from strength to strength in terms of its net profit operations but also owns, currently at least, East-West Airlines. It has taken over Lloyd Aviation, which is a rapidly expanding airline; it controls Kendall Airways, which operates in three States; and it has taken over Aeropelican Air Services Pty Ltd, which flies charters between Sydney and Newcastle.

What do we find when we look at Australian Airlines? It is going in the opposite direction. It has had to sell off Air Queensland after a disastrous investment of some $30m. Its main profits in the last financial year have come more from the sale of assets and a miserable $2m from some six resorts that it operates in Queensland than from any commercial activity in relation to the operation of airlines. In the last financial year its supposedly record profit was $39.16m, but only $10.56m of that sum was earned by flying passengers. On that basis, if one applied a price-earning ratio of 12 : 1, Australian Airlines would be worth $126m compared with its current capital base of $130m. So if one separates out the actual running of the airline and looks at the profit that has been derived, the downturn is of the order of 65 per cent in profits over the last 12 months.

The Government has been told by Australian Airlines that it is in desperate need of the capital injection. We know that the Government will be extremely reluctant to provide that in its present category as a public enterprise because it will have an adverse effect on the public sector borrowing requirement. What is the obvious alternative? It is to put it out to the private sector and to allow those funds to be obtained in the capital markets. It will do that in due course. As night follows day, this Government will privatise Australian Airlines. The delay is for the sake of pacifying and appeasing the union movement. It has nothing to do with the interest of the Australian community, nothing to do with airline consumers and nothing to do with this poor little outfit that is bleeding to death. It is all for the sake of trying to persuade Mr Kelty and his mates that somehow privatisation is not anathema and that it has something going for it, and that, hopefully the union movement will be ruled by its head and not its heart, as Senator Evans now seems to think is an acceptable approach to these decisions.

The reality is that Australian Airlines has both hands behind its back whilst, to mix metaphors, Ansett Airlines has been given a free kick in the goal square. It is abundantly obvious that Australian Airlines will not be able to go anywhere in the next few years, while Ansett Airlines will go from strength to strength.

If we look at the ramifications of the policy decisions that have been announced, they have been put forward under the rubric of open competition. `Open skies' is the sort of headline that has no doubt warmed Senator Evans's heart. But that is nonsense. This is not open competition at all. It is a closed door policy. We find that there will be no competition from outside this country. There will be a limit of 15 per cent foreign investment in domestic carriers. There will be no entitlement whatsoever for any foreign airline to operate on domestic routes, not even little New Zealand Airlines. Whereas, of course, New Zealand was happy for us to go in and make its airlines more competitive, we are not prepared to do the same.

Where will the competition come from? Senator Evans is on the record as saying all sorts of things such as, `There won't be great changes', `We do not expect that much will happen as a result'. That is almost `steady as you go' stuff. He is hosing down any prospect of significant competition. He does not want to see the sorts of decent discount fares, new routes, new airlines, carriers and operators that sprang up in the United States of America. Let us not be misled by the furphy of bankruptcies that have occurred there. As those who believe in competition well know, the right to go broke is a very important aspect of competition. There is no natural monopoly in the operation of small carriers and commuters. If one is talking about a People's Express type of operation, all one needs is one aircraft. One does not even have to own it; one can lease it. So it is a nonsense to talk about a natural monopoly.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you do that you will go broke in three months.

—Let them try. If they make the commercial judgment that they will inevitably go broke in three months, why would they take it on? That is absolute rubbish. No one would pretend for a moment that people would go into business just to go broke-except poor old Australian Airlines, which has no choice but to go quietly and slowly broke over the next three years. New Zealand will not be allowed in. What will there be in place to stop predatory pricing and the like?

SPEECH.PARA: The history of Ansett Airlines is such that it has done everything in its power to put East-West Airlines Ltd out of business-not just the ultimate takeover.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good deal of what ought not to be within its power.

—Indeed, and by means of court actions and otherwise, it made very sure that there was no prospect of East-West being able to survive as a viable alternative. Of course, East-West was the only one that did offer any significant prospect of real competition. Of course, we have had Senator Evans saying that there will be no significant change. Presumably, that means that he does not envisage any serious competition. Of course, East-West used to charge cheap air fares, was quite happy to gate-crash some of the trunk air routes and was a viable competitor. Now it looks as though it has disappeared. It will always remember that, when it tried to expand, it faced a severe shortage of airport terminal space. Ansett is on the record as saying that it will fight tooth and nail to ensure that it is not forced to share airport terminals with other competitors. There has been very strong resistance from both Ansett and Australian Airlines to any importation of aircraft, expansion of routes or proposals for cheap new services on key routes. So it is quite clear that the leopard is not going to change its spots just because there has been some sort of announcement that the two airlines policy should come to an end. It should have happened long ago, as we know, and it will now come about.

SPEECH.PARA: This is essentially a timid and cautious decision and one for which the Government deserves no credit. The reality is that there will be virtually no competition in the airline industry. The lead in the saddlebags of Australian Airlines is unbelievable. It will still be required to comply with the superannuation requirements and the industrial regulations red tape that prevails. Senator Evans will not give an answer as to whether the Loan Council requirements will be lifted. In all sorts of ways the industry will still be regulated and controlled. All air fares will be subject to review by the Prices Surveillance Authority. Trade Practices legislation will be invoked if necessary. The Trade Practices Commission will, to the best of its ability, I suppose, try to restrain Ansett. But the prospects are not very good. Senator Evans clearly agrees with that.

So in all sorts of areas what we find is that there has been no encouragement at all for Australian Airlines to become really viable and competitive. Every opportunity has been provided for Ansett to go from strength to strength. That is not what we need in this country at present. The Government should have had the courage, the intestinal fortitude, to allow in competition, if necessary from overseas and at the very least from New Zealand. I quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review by Gregory Hywood, a well known-nigh notorious-acolyte of the Government in many areas, and particularly of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Yet what did Mr Hywood have to say about Senator Evans's disastrous series of announcements. He called it a cautious compromise. He said:
By preventing the entry of major foreign carriers into the market, the Government has closed off the only realistic source of competition.
The main concern of Labor appears to have been to protect the major players, minimise the political fallout, yet gain the kudos of increasing competition.
The decision contains little of the boldness which underpinned Labor's decision to allow the entry of . . . foreign banks . . . the primary aim was to not disadvantage particular existing operators.
Ansett is particularly well looked after on the domestic routes. All-
that is all the existing competitors-
are protected from the uncertainty of powerful outside competition under the new regime.
Senator Evans conceded this yesterday when he said the changes would produce `niche competition' . . . from small operators on feeder routes.

This is fringe player stuff. This is not in the main event. This is not competition. Mr Hywood goes on in the same vein, and one could expatiate at length if the time were available. It is not just the Financial Review and the Half- penys of this world, it is not just those who are perceptive enough to realise who the one great beneficiary of this fraudulent exercise is, it is the people of Australia and the consumers of airline services who will most regret what has happened, the ball having been dropped in such a scandalous manner. I only regret that Senator Evans, who would appear to be a champion of change and prepared to take initiatives, has not taken the opportunity in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, it takes a fair bit of cheek to become a politician, to thrust oneself into the public gaze, to demand to be taken notice of and then to assume that people will take one seriously. It takes even more cheek, I guess, to be an Opposition politician, because everyone knows that one often has to stand up in this place and oppose things for the sheer hell of it; oppose things which one knows are right and which one would do oneself if one had half a chance. To generate the kind of synthetic indignation that we have just heard from Senator Alston really does take a degree of cheek and brazenness that is entirely appropriate for a competent member of an Opposition. (Quorum formed) I was saying that it takes a fair bit of cheek to be a politician; it takes lot more cheek to be a good Opposition politician, but to produce the kind of proposition that we have before us today requires a degree of cheek that is not a common or garden variety-it is stupendous, it is gothic proportion cheek.

SPEECH.PARA: To shed crocodile tears for Australian Airlines, the socialist enterprise that the parties opposite and every other tory party since Menzies have been trying to kick the legs out from under; to assault the Labor Government for alleged shortfalls in its aviation deregulation package; to do so when the parties opposite have been in government for 27 of the 35 years of the existence of the two-airline policy, when they were there from 1952 through to 1972, the first 20 years of it, and well and truly after the policy got out of its childhood into its adolescence and there was a mature system which manifestly no longer justified that degree of bureaucratic interventionism, and when they were in government again from 1976 to 1983 and still did absolutely nothing about deregulating the industry, about moving down any of these paths they are getting so excited about today-all that requires the kind of cheek for which they ought to be locked up and the key thrown away. The Age editorial yesterday put it about as nicely and neatly as it possibly could be put when it said:

While the Liberal Party has huffed and puffed about the benefits of freer commercial competition and less official control, the Government . . . has moved further towards economic deregulation than any of its predecessors.

I think Senator Alston should be ashamed to show his face in Victoria when the people of Victoria, having read an editorial such as that, will realise just how synthetic, how hollow, how hypocritical, how empty, how frustrated and how envious his speech was here today. The matter of public importance says that there has been a refusal to open the Australian aviation industry to genuine competition. What absolute nonsense-nonsense on stilts, as Jeremy Bentham would say. Only Senator Puplick would recognise the allusion, I appreciate, but at least he has got a guffaw out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the contrary.

—Maybe Senator Stone, too. His erudition is already getting a bit faded around the edges. What we are really doing, of course, is removing four basic controls to create a competitive environment. We are removing controls over imports; we are removing controls over capacity; we are removing controls over fares; and, above all, we are removing controls over route entry. What else is that but opening up the Australian airline industry to genuine competition? We are reinforcing that competitive environment by applying the Trade Practices Act and indicating a willingness to go as far as it becomes necessary to do, if weaknesses show up through a subsequent course of judicial interpretation, to ensure that there are effective anti-dominance provisions operating in that legal area, the effective operation of anti-anti-predatory pricing and all the rest of the things that are crucial to ensure competition.

SPEECH.PARA: We are making arrangements to ensure guaranteed access to terminal gate entry for potential new entrants. We are, in all those ways, creating a competitive environment that will, in fact, operate as such and produce genuine and real advantages over time for Australian consumers. But the nub of the complaint seems to be that we are not allowing in foreign airlines; we are not allowing in international aviation operators to make a major splash on the domestic stage. True it is that we are not. We are not excluding, by the way, foreign investment completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, 15 per cent.

—It is not 15 per cent. Senator Alston should get his act together. It is as much investment as the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) is prepared to allow on a case-by-case analysis, provided that investment is not by an existing international aviation operator running services to Australia. If there is foreign capital out there, if there is a foreign airline out there in the Ozarks or Arkansas or Central Europe, or somewhere else, that wants to do the thing Ansett Airlines has done in New Zealand-that is, establish a domestic operation in Australia-it will be perfectly welcome to do so, subject to ordinary FIRB constraints. The 15 per cent is just a limitation on the degree of ownership or investment that can be made by international operators coming into Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Why have we set that restriction? Why have we set a limitation on foreign airlines coming in? I will tell the Senate why. First, it would create a manifestly unfair competitive environment for the domestic operators. Consider a situation where United Airlines, with its 50 million passengers a year and 373 planes, considered coming into the Australian market as a marginal cost operation, having elsewhere amortised its infrastructure costs, its fleet costs. Consider American Airlines, with its 46 million passengers a year and 330 planes, or Continental, with its 600 planes, choosing to do it. How then would any of the domestic operations have a chance of surviving in that sort of environment? How would we weigh the benefits of the competition that would flow from that entry against the damage and havoc that would be caused to the domestic Australian industry as a result? That is one consideration, but by no means the only one. Secondly, how do we justify allowing the entry of foreign international airlines into Australia in an environment where those other countries running those airlines themselves lock international competitors out? The American system was not an open skies system; it was a closed system so far as foreign airlines were concerned. Qantas is not allowed to fly inside America; no other international airline is. Qantas is not allowed to fly domestic routes in any other part of the world and that is the norm in international aviation. It is a cut-throat business and those sorts of barriers apply everywhere, even in countries having the most intense alleged philosophical commitment to the kind of competitive environment that honourable senators opposite are talking about in a wishful, fantasy sort of way.

The third reason we are keeping foreign airlines out is simply the necessary consequences that would flow so far as the Australian domestic airlines' own competitive response would be concerned. The only way they would want to go in that kind of situation would be international. Ansett has made no bones about that and I believe that it would not be possible for the Government to resist such a claim being made on the grounds of fair and equitable commercial opportunity. Accordingly, we would have an undermining of the single designation policy which has been at the absolute heart and centrepiece of our international aviation policy for the last goodness knows how many years and there is a very rational reason for that. To allow a fragmentation of our international airline operations, to allow a domestic operator to take the eyes out of the few really profitable routes that there are, such as trans-Tasman and Australia-Japan in particular, would not produce, in my analysis, net gains for the Australian aviation industry or the Australian economy. It would create a fragmentation situation which would be increasingly unsustainable.

I regret that Senator Alston has been obliged, by the weight of this argument, to leave the chamber. I can understand why he should scurry for cover. It is not a situation that is manageable, that is acceptable in an international aviation environment where all the emphasis is the other way-not towards fragmentation but towards consolidation and towards the creation of mega-enterprises.

It is a much longer and more complicated argument to spell it all out, but the only point I simply make to summarise all that is that there is a much more complex and delicate interrelationship between the domestic and international aviation markets and environments than the Opposition seems prepared to acknowledge. Perhaps it is more than it is even aware of. Many considerations also apply. By way of parenthesis perhaps I should just add some of the more romantic solutions that are perpetrated, for example, as far as our little Kiwi battlers across the Tasman are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you let them in?

—Senator Stone asks: Why do we not let them in? Because it is an international airline and all the same considerations to which I have referred apply. If that were to occur, it would create exactly the same sort of competitive response by Ansett. It would be a marginal cost operation if they were to come in in their own right. Were they to buy a piece of the action that might change the circumstances somewhat, but it would still have the capacity that any international operation has to spread its costs and not be able to be running in a truly competitive operation. Moreover, it is just naive to have this perception that we owe some sort of obligation to our trans-Tasman cousins out of some kind of sentiment rather than hard-headed economic analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter is that the balance of commercial advantage, in terms of the international aviation agreement that presently exists between Australia and New Zealand, lies squarely and wholly on the New Zealand side. There are many more opportunities for the New Zealand carrier, Air New Zealand, to take Australian passengers on routes, for example, across the Pacific, than there are for the Australian airlines to take New Zealand passengers. There is an imbalance and all the abstract purist argument in the world that one might hear on occasions like this from the Senator Stones of this world does not alter that set of dynamic real world realities and the implications that would flow from opening the skies in the way that has been suggested. It just does not make sense.

Let us come to that part of the proposal which deals with privatisation that perhaps attracted even more synthetic indignation and even more huff and puff, using the language of the Age, than that about the competitive environment. We are told that this is a shameful and politically motivated deferral of the overwhelming case for immediate privatisation. The proposal, to the extent that it makes any grammatical sense, assumes what has to be proved and that is not something that can be assumed. It has to be proved that privatisation is the answer to the problems, such as they are, of Australian Airlines.

Two reasons are usually advanced for privatisation: First, managerial efficiency and the benefits that will flow from it in terms of the dynamic environment of the private sector compared to that of the public sector; and secondly, the particular question of capital funding and capital needs. We are addressing both of those questions in the context of Australian Airlines and it is simply not to be assumed that privatisation is the only way through the problems that Australian Airlines has. As far as managerial efficiency is concerned, this is something that is absolutely at the centre of the strategy for Australian Airlines that was mapped out in my statement earlier this week. We are tackling the problem head on, recognising that there is a problem and that Australian Airlines has to be leaner and tauter, that it has to have a much greater degree of managerial freedom, it has to have a much greater degree of commercial responsibility, it has to be relieved of a number of the more idiotic Public Service shackles and controls that people such as Senator Stone have spent most of their adult life mapping out and applying to organisations like this--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to do better than that.

—And sometimes in denying the results of their week's work when they have a foot up on the bar on a Friday evening. Nonetheless, they have been doing it for a generation or more, and that is the legacy that Australian Airlines now has and that is the legacy of which it must be relieved. Our policy, as articulated earlier this week, is designed to do just that. Incorporation will take place as soon as possible with all the benefits that will flow from that.
—Is that the situation you repealed when you first came to office?

—That is right. Unlike the Bourbons opposite who learn nothing and forget nothing, we are capable of learning from experience, of re-analysing situations and changing our minds when the weight of argument, the weight of analysis, the weight of evidence, points that way. We have changed our minds. We have thought about it and we have come to the view that incorporation would be a highly desirable step to take. It would create a situation where the directors become fully accountable, fully responsible, in a normal commercial environment for the consequences of their decisions, and this in itself, quite apart from the particular controls and things, the removal of which are associated with the incorporation strategy, we believe will create a whole new ethos within the organisation, which will be thoroughly helpful in achieving the sorts of objectives we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Associated with that incorporation, we are talking about the simultaneous removal of a number of discretionary Public Service, public sector, controls and limitations which presently apply-the approval of contracts of quite small amounts of money, detailed terms and conditions of borrowing and leasing arrangements having to be approved by the Government; the investment of surplus money having to be approved; the choice of auditor having to be approved; dividends having to be recommended; and provision of insurance against risk. All these things we will strip away, and it is long overdue. It is something that could have been done at any time in those 27 of the 35 years that the two airlines agreement has been in operation. But it was not done by the Opposition and now it comes in here and sheds crocodile tears and displays synthetic indignation about the way in which we are doing it now. We are doing it for a good reason. We are doing it because we believe it will result in greater managerial efficiency. It does not necessarily follow at all that we have to privatise to achieve these sorts of results. All of these things can be done consistently with maintaining fully 100 per cent public ownership.

Beyond that we are looking at a series of more significant and far-reaching controls-on industrial relations co-ordination, on superannuation schemes that are applicable, on salary caps through the Remuneration Tribunal and, of course, on the borrowing restrictions, the Loan Council ceilings and so on that are presently applicable. It may well be that most, if not all, of those restrictions can also be stripped away in the context of not a shift to a privately owned organisation. But while it remains in the public sector we are looking intensely and closely at those possibilities and the results of that analysis will be known in a few months time.

Beyond that there is, of course, the second leg of the argument about privatisation, and that is the question of capital funding. Capital funding has a couple of dimensions to it. One is borrowing and the other is injections of equity. Again, on the borrowing side, there is a question as to the extent to which borrowing capacity would be aided by relief from the present Loan Council restrictions. It is not necessarily incompatible with the organisation remaining in the public sector that those Loan Council restrictions be lifted. Whether that can be achieved is something again, as I said a moment ago, we are looking at. To that extent, borrowing would, of course, be much easier. It is not the end of the matter because gearing ratios are still important for an organisation like this. One does not want to be too heavily indebted and have too much of one's capital tied up in that way. So the question of equity injections will remain important. It is the case that Australian Airlines will need $200m plus or minus of equity injection in the next two to three years. Whether or not there proves to be difficulty in accommodating that need within the existing budgetary arrangements is a matter for decision by the Government. It is not a matter on which conclusions can be assumed. It is a matter of the kinds of priorities that we want to apply.
Debate interrupted.
